recipientOrganization.name: Lads Need Dads CIC
recipientOrganization.description: Who we are: Lads Need Dads CIC is a Not-For-Profit Community Interest Company, based in Tendring, North East Essex, set up to prevent potential problems and address existing ones where boys are missing a father figure in their lives. Our Mission: To empower and enable boys aged 11-15 with absent fathers or limited access to a male role model, to be motivated, responsible, capable, resilient and emotionally competent to prevent them from coming at risk of under achieving, offending, exclusion or dropping out of school. What we do: • Help boys through male-led group mentoring, to cope with problems and issues faced at home and school, and explore the important choices they face in their adolescent development, to prevent escalation of negative behaviour. • Provide boys with opportunities for adventure, to be tested and challenged, both physically and mentally. • Provide boys with practical life-skill training, community volunteering and peer mentoring opportunities. • Raise awareness and understanding of the important role fathers play in the emotional, mental and educational development and well-being of boys. Why we do it: In 2013 the Centre for Social Justice published Fractured Families: Why stability matters, which highlighted an alarming trend of fatherlessness across the UK. It found that a teenager sitting their GCSEs is more likely to own a smartphone than live with their father, (only 57 per cent of 15-year olds are still living with their fathers while 62 per cent own a smartphone), (1). Nationally almost one quarter of families with dependent children are lone-parent families. (2) This figure rises significantly in our poorest neighbourhoods, and can be as high as 75 percent. (3) Blanden (2006) (4), found a father’s low interest in his son’s education, for instance, reduces his boy’s chances of escaping poverty by 25% and at the more extreme end, 76% of all male prisoners in England and Wales had an absent father. Statistically males are the more vulnerable gender when it comes to alcohol and drug misuse, victims of murder, victims of suicide, homelessness. Lads Need Dads was set up to provide a preventative and early-intervention response to an ever-increasing social issue. Our services: ‘EQUIP’, is a six-month self-development group-work programme held in school including bush-craft and outdoor activities supported by a facilitator and a team of male mentors. Equips’ aim is to help boys cope with problems and issues faced at home and school, and explore the important choices they face in their adolescent development, to prevent escalation of negative behaviour. Engage, a practical life-skill and community volunteering programme follows Equip and takes place in the community for six-months and involves boys attending practical life-skill workshops and together with thier mentors, doing voluntary work for lone parents, pensioners and people with a disability within their local community. Jobs include, DIY, painting and decorating, gardening, shed building, etc. Inspire, a peer mentoring programme incorporating inspirational speakers and visits to inspiring places, completes the 18-month programme. We have run the 18-month pilot once through between March 2016 and August 2017 with excellent outcomes. We started another Equip Programme in May this year. This ended this month (Nov) and the boys off this programme are now attending Engage, the second part of the programme. Alongside the programme we provide on-going support for mums and carers via workshops, coffee mornings and a face-book support group. We raise awareness within the community by giving talks and presentations to community groups, attending public events etc. We run an open-ended check-in group for graduates of the programme one evening a month to keep the arm of support in place, should they need it. We run a fishing club in the summer which is open to any boy on the programme, graduate or new boy who fits our criteria. We are just about to start a guitar club for boys who want to learn to play the guitar but who can't afford lessons. All our services are provided free of charge. We have a growing team of 14 male volunteer male mentors, between the ages of 29 and 70, from a wide range of backgrounds and from the local community. Our Director board is made up of four professionals from education, social care, statutory services and the voluntary sector. We are just entering into our next round of recruitment so anticipate our volunteer numbers increasing. References: (1) Ibid, Ofcom, Children and Parents: Media User and Attitudes Report, 2013 (2) Office of National Statistics, General Lifestyle Survey Overview: A Report on the General Lifestyle Survey 2011, Chapter 3 – Households, families and people, 7 March 2013 [accessed via: http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/dcp171776_302210.pdf (2/7/14)] (3) Centre for Social Justice, Fractured Families: Why stability matters, London: Centre for Social Justice, 2013, p32. (4) Blanden, J. (2006). ‘Bucking the trend’: What enables those who are disadvantaged in childhood to succeed later in life? Working Paper No 31 Corporate Document Services. London: Department for Work and Pensions. (5) Prison Reform Trust 2015.

recipientOrganization.description: Talk Listen Care, is a newly founded (CIO) Charity No:1174985 Providing Accessible emotional/mental health support by way of quality counselling and wellbeing services to meet the need of disadvantaged people within our community, alleviating emotional suffering, improving life prospects and preventing long term mental health illness. Our work is 100 % volunteer led with a highly qualified and dedicated multi-disciplinary team offering a huge amount of time and value to our service users, charity and community. Some of Talk Listen Care Services • Accessible emergency emotional first aid (Drop in) no appointment or waiting list Therapeutic Art group for young people in partnership with ~Essex County Council youth services. • One to one counselling = Adults, Children, Adolescents and family work with a variety of models offered. • Group work for specific vulnerable groups • Outreach, the same as above but in other locations, church halls, youth groups, libraries and Schools. • Psycho-educational we will run a variety or courses such as ‘How to cope with a teenager ‘, ‘parenting twins’ and general parenting. Help with sleep and exam stress workshops. • Critical Incident Debriefing – Available to Schools, and organisations in the aftermath of a trauma. • Mindfulness, relaxation and stress management. We offer to support to people suffering from emotional disturbance and or emerging mental health issues including :Stress + School phobia + Friendship difficulties Anger + Abuse + divorce + Bereavement + Sibling difficulties Caring responsibility +Eating disorders + Adoption + Anxiety Drugs/Alcohol + Confidence + Depression + Self Harm Attachment issues + Sexual Identity﻿ + Self -Esteem + Identity

recipientOrganization.name: The MAZE Group CiC
recipientOrganization.description: The MAZE is a unique approach, which offers an insight into how children with additional needs experience the world around them in order that parents can better understand their children and why they respond in the way that they do. Specifically, the MAZE Approach examines these 3 key areas of difficulty for additional needs: • Sensory Processing Difficulties that 95% of ASD children experience and that can explain many unusual or challenging behaviours. • Communication difficulties that the children experience, which are often not detected even if they present with functional, fluent speech. • Social Understanding and an exploration of how an impaired ability to make social sense of situations leads to social difficulties, with a focus on the value of Social Stories. We offer training in the Maze Approach to parents, schools and other professionals. In the training for parents (which is what we are asking for partial funding for) we cover: The topics covered are: •Session 1: Introductions •Session 2: Sensory Processing Difficulties •Session 3: Communication Strategies •Session 4: Social Understanding •Session 5: Lifestyle issues (sleep, continence, diet) •Session 6: Behaviour Management - using positive strategies Session 7: Positive Family Relationships •Session 8: Behaviour Management - limit setting and consequences •Session 9: Functional Behaviour Analysis •Session 10: My Childs Development •Session 11: What about me? Building resilience •Session 12: Planning For The Future - moving on Our service users are the parents and carers of children with additional needs. This may be a learning difficulty, physical disability, autism, ADHD, cerebral palsy or any other additional or special need. We have worked with parents of children with a wide range of difficulties. Many parents do not have sufficient knowledge about their child's condition and are not provided with this information on diagnosis. They are often socially isolated because of their child's difficulties, which commonly include challenging behaviour and they also struggle to access appropriate activities out of school hours. These families experience further difficulties with accessing the appropriate education and support for their child, which can result in school exclusions or tribunals. Additionally, the families face difficulties in accessing services such as O/T, speech therapy or short breaks/services through Social Care and also face very restricted leisure opportunities Here’s what our parents have to say about it: “My life changed. I was lost and I didn’t know what to do. After Maze I have the tools that I need to help myself and my child. My child is happier. Less arguments in my household. Siblings are happy and not fighting.” “My son has noticed positive changes to his and my relationship as a result of alterations to our lifestyle…I’ve learned so many positive strategies from Sue and other guests and attendees to use at home, and feel very supported.” “[I have] a better understanding of how my daughter thinks, giving me methods to deal with challenging situations…we’re a lot happier.” “It helped me understand my daughter more… I see people I can relate with and felt I am not alone. This session is making me strong….best course I have ever done for my daughter and myself.” “I feel better able to communicate with my child confidently.” We have a hundreds of feedback forms filled with comments like this and 99.6% of parents highly recommend the MAZE.

recipientOrganization.description: Kids Inspire supports children and young people age 0-25 who are at an educational, social and/or economic disadvantage. Many of the children have experienced trauma, bereavement, family breakdown, bullying, or have emerging mental health issues. These experiences/ disorders lead to emotional and behavioural difficulties, such as self-harm, substance abuse, risk-taking, truancy, anxiety, depression, aggression or withdrawal. As a result, young people struggle to engage with their education, families and communities; which in turn prevents them reaching their full potential. Without support, issues continue to disrupt children’s education and risk escalating and continuing into adulthood. Kids Inspire create bespoke packages of support tailored to individual needs. Where it will benefit the child, we also support their parents and siblings. Services include the following: * Individual Therapy: including clinically proven counselling, Arts Psychotherapy, complementary therapies and talking therapy. *Group Work: including Lunch Club, Youth Forum, Dramatherapy and Filmmaking. *Mentoring: support and guidance on a one-to-one basis, provided by trained volunteers. *Coaching: supporting disadvantaged young people to improve their emotional health and mental wellbeing. Referrals come from local GPs, Primary/ Secondary/ Special Schools, EWMHS, Social Services, paediatricians, Health Visitors, Family Solutions teams, third sector agencies, and self-referrals. Kids Inspire empowers children and young people to make sense of their experiences and feelings to improve their emotional wellbeing. We achieve this by supporting service users to develop the knowledge and tools required to build resilience and coping mechanisms; enabling them to manage independently long-term. We address root causes rather than simply treating symptoms, to achieve outcomes that last. Kids Inspire believe that supporting children to cope with emotional and behavioural difficulties is essential for them to reach their full potential.
recipientOrganization.name: Kids Inspire

recipientOrganization.name: London Bus Theatre Company
recipientOrganization.description: The London Bus Theatre Company aims to increase young people's confidence, self-esteem, employability and transferable life skills through a range of drama and film making activities. We focus on the most deprived areas within Essex where we can get to the root of problems within communities and instigate social change . We provide beneficiary led long term sustainable projects and employment and volunteering opportunities for young people and change their lives for the better. We provide Councils, NHS Trusts, Essex Police, PCC and schools and colleges with drama workshops and DVD's on issues such as bullying, drugs, alcohol, antisocial behaviour and job interview techniques. Approximately 16,000 young people benefit from our workshops in schools every year. In 2012 we received funding for three years from The Big Lottery, The Arts Council and Esmee Fairbairn Foundation to provide a film project for 300 young people from Canvey Island. This resulted in the feature film “Angels vs Bullies” being signed by Cineworld and featuring on The BBC and ITV news. We are the only TIE group in Essex currently funded by The Arts Council. We have received sponsorship from BP, Tesco, Umbro and Starbucks.

recipientOrganization.description: SOS Rape Crisis is a charity providing specialist confidential and non-judgemental support for survivors of any form of sexual violence. The aims and objectives of the organisation are: *Relieve the sickness and distress of survivors who have suffered any form of sexual violence. *Promote education and research in the subject of rape and its effects on the survivor, whether physical, medical, psychological or social. *Encourage staff and volunteers to continuously train and develop to enhance wellbeing of survivors. *Publish educative and informative material about rape. *Obtain help and support where needed through close contact with government authorities, health services and voluntary organisations. *Set up a co-ordinated group of contacts to further the charitable aims and objectives of the charity. *Raise money for the purpose of the charity on such terms and on such security as may be thought fit. *Accept donations and legacies. ACTIVITIES: The service supports victims from the communities of Southend on Sea, Castle Pont and Rochford, Essex - operating within dedicated, safe premises as well as rural outreach where necessary - the services helps survivors move forward with their lives and make appropriate choices. The specialist service provided by SOS Rape Crisis includes: *Information & Support Helpline operated by qualified sexual violence counsellors. *Support & Advocacy service providing practical support and guidance for adults on housing, benefits as well as support for adult survivors of sexual violence going through the criminal justice system. *Under 18's ISVA support service - providing advice and support for young people and families going through the criminal justice system *Face to face specialist sexual violence counselling session for young people aged 11 years upwards as well as adult counselling services for males and females. *Dedicated, specialist Under 11's therapy services for young children under the age of 11 years. *Young Persons therapeutic support group services including awareness and prevention activity as well as dealing with issues as a result of the violence such as: self esteem; self confidence; negative body image etc. *Promotional and educative service in the subject of sexual abuse and rape and its effects on survivors, working directly with schools, colleges and partners in the local area. *Therapeutic Yoga sessions - enabling survivors to relieve their thoughts and feelings through yoga. *Parent support programme. One to one counselling and/or support group work for parents or young people/children who have suffered child sexual abuse or sexual violence. Enabling them to understand behaviours and attitudes and to provide suggested coping strategies to use themselves and with their children to move forward positively. *Southend WAVE - working in partnership with range of agencies to provide women in prostitution or the sex industry opportunities to make different choices. Ultimately providing route out of prostitution. *Adult Peer support group - providing ongoing therapeutic support to women who have suffered sexual violence and/or abuse. To mange behaviours and feelings to enable a positive way forward in life. *Art Journaling group for adult survivors - enabling them to express their thoughts and feelings through creative activity such as collage; paint; poetry etc. *Public awareness activity within communities of Southend on Sea including range of fund-raising activities and public survey opportunities ie: market pitch, community events and campaign involvement. *Training and presentations to voluntary and statutory partners to consistently raise awareness of scope of specialist support services available. *Representation on key stakeholder groups across the community including: Safeguarding Adults Board; Missing Children & Child Exploitation Board; One in Four Group; Inter-professionals Group; Southend Information Advisory Group etc. *Engagement in Partnership working with Synergy Essex (Essex Rape Crisis Partnership) - working closely with CARA (Centre for Action on Rape and Abuse) and SERICC (South Essex Rape and Incest Crisis Centre). *Co-production and consultation activity with survivors, public and staff/volunteers to consistently identify gaps in service and enable clear development and planning going forward to meet growing demand and identify needs. *Dedication to Continued Professional and Personal Development for staff and volunteers including working with local training providers to enable student placement opportunities. *Lisa's Line - clothing rail for survivors unable to resource attire for interviews or new employment positions. Using high quality clothing donations to assist in times of need on a loan or keep basis. *Support to Local Authority commissioned production 'Prince Charming' - providing voice in awareness raising to schools on specialist support available for survivors of sexual violence. *Weekly drop in provision for Family Mosaic to support survivors requiring specialist support and advice on housing issues. *First Contact Navigator Triage service for all new referrals - one point of contact at initial stage of referral whether self referral or organisation/agency referral *First Meeting programme to support and welcome new survivors into the specialist support service - enabling clear pathway of support to be identified from the first session. *Ensuring safe, welcoming space for all service users including all ages; all genders; supporters/relatives as well as survivors.
recipientOrganization.name: SOS Rape Crisis

recipientOrganization.description: Fixers is a champion of youth social action and is the driving force behind giving 16-25 year olds a voice. We reach out into communities to find disadvantaged and isolated young people who build unique projects around issues that matter most to them. Whether it is tackling mental health stigmas, raising awareness of physical disabilities, or discouraging LGBTQ bullying, we work with young people on the subjects close to their hearts. Fixers believes that giving young people a voice is key to helping them reach their full potential: using their disadvantages to transform their lives and the lives of others. All too often, young people do not have a platform through which to campaign about the things they care about. Fixers is dedicated to giving them that platform. The innovative projects can take whichever path that the young people feel will be most effective in their communities. There are six key steps to the project: 1. The Planning Phase Our dedicated Young People’s Coordinator meets with the young people and helps them to decide on the project topic, hone their ideas, create a compelling message and build a solid plan for delivery. The young people will work through their ideas for what needs to be fixed based on their own experiences, why change is needed and identify who needs to hear their voice. All meetings will be held at locations convenient to the young people. 2. The Creative Phase The young people then meet with our professional Creative Resources team and produce the project resource: this could be a film, poster campaign, leaflet or brochure, or any other format; we are led by the young people and their goals for the project. They research existing resources, help write scripts and case studies and have the opportunity to star in their own resource. 3. The Engagement Phase While the resource is being created, the young people, with the help of the YPC, establish connections with organisations in their community which can help by providing content, quotes and further important contacts. 4. The Launch Phase We hold a special launch event in the local area, premiering the completed resource to the target audience within the community. Key influencers will be in attendance; this can include parents, teachers, healthcare professionals, local government representatives and local and national media. The young people share their stories and begin driving their messages out into the public, using their voices to create positive change. 5. The Dissemination Phase Both the resources and young people’s stories are featured on our website and promoted on social media to thousands of people. We have over 30,000 followers on social media and, on average, 3,250 unique visitors for each news story on our website. We also offer a press release and many projects go on to be featured in local and national media. Fixers also works in partnership with ITV News, and once a month in every single region, we have a slot on the local news to showcase a local project. This totals twelve TV slots every month, reaching an audience of over 8 million. 6. The Legacy Phase Once the project has been launched, the young people and their coordinator reflect on their project and plan next steps. We ask young people to evaluate what they set out to do and what they have achieved at the end of their Fixers project and ensure they have plans to continue in the way they wish.
recipientOrganization.name: Public Service Broadcasting Trust Limited

recipientOrganization.description: To relieve the social, emotional, physical and educational needs of carers and their families living in the Rochford District. This is achieved through a range of group sessions, individual interventions and awareness raising/training; including respite groups, a schools based one to one programme available to all schools in the district, online support forums, advocacy and information services, training for staff and volunteers working with young people, carers and their families across the district. SCAFT works with young carers aged 6-18 years, and is continuing to see much growth in referrals relating to 6-8year olds over the past year. Support is offered through separate primary and secondary aged respite group sessions, run at two venues across the district to aid ease of access. Each group runs fortnightly giving a total of 8 groups a month. The groups offer respite from their caring responsibilities, a chance to meet and share with others in a similar situation, staff and peer support, art and other creative activities, games and sports and a range of informal and formal learning opportunities. The one to one schools service has continued to grow since being expanded to include primary schools 18 months ago and we have recently increased our staffing to boost capacity in this service. This service gives vital support to young carers unable to access the group evenings due to their caring commitments and is able to provide advocacy to young people struggling to balance their education with the demands of caring on issues such as lateness or absence, late or missed homework, or peer relationships and bullying. SCAFT has now become an accredited ADSAN learning provider in order to increase the range of learning opportunities available to young carers. We are integrating the ASDAN ‘Stepping Stones’ programme into our primary sessions, aimed at bolstering our younger users learning and social skills to improve their ability to make use of other educational opportunities such as school. The secondary groups will be undertaking a range of more targeted short courses, the first of which is a peer mentoring project to develop our users ability to support each other, with new skills and techniques. We hope that this programme will led to the establishment of Peer based Young Carers Ambassadors in each secondary school to act as a point of first contact for young people finding themselves in a caring role. SCAFT provides adult carers with respite groups, advice and information, counselling and advocacy services, working to reduce social isolation and improve wellbeing. SCAFT is also now looking to establish a support service for parents of children who are carers as a recent pilot project in the north of the county by Action for Family Carers showed a real need for this type of support. We are undertaking a consultation with families to establish the level of need locally and what shape this support should take. We expect this service to utilize our Young Carers Support Workers to work with parents to better support their child, as well as our Adult Carer Support Worker to provide direct support to the parent, such as benefit advice and counselling. ECC’s recent decision not to continue funding lower tier young carers services, in favour of a more targeted needs dependant approach is likely to have a major effect on the need for our services and we are currently investigating how best this can be met as many are likely to fall below the threshold for ECC support, but still be in need. We are also currently investigating the best way to extend our services from term-time only to providing at least some support during school breaks, particularly the long summer holiday.
recipientOrganization.name: Supporting Carers and Families Together

recipientOrganization.description: We aim to enhance lives by providing bespoke support for 11-25 year olds to overcome day to day difficulties. This is achieved by boosting confidence by helping young people identify their strengths and develop strategies, through opportunities for them to feel more confident and empowered. Our Drop-in’s provide 1-1 sessions with a Support Worker allowing a young person to explore their difficulties and feelings, in a safe environment. Through these sessions we help them to improve their communication with peers, families and agencies so they are more resilient. By learning skills that will help them to problem solve their issues in the future more positively. By identifying their qualities, we progress onto a range of youth led group activities, this helps them to hone in on their often, hidden talents. Current projects include: Harwich Inspired Youth Action (HIYA)for 11-18 years-Young People making a difference to their community. Wildlife Project-for 11-25 years- Young People involved in activities that support local wildlife Volunteer Programme-for 18-25 years-an opportunity to develop their knowledge and practical skills. Each of the above provides a base for Young People to develop their ideas and gives them the opportunity to try new things.

recipientOrganization.description: St Stephen’s Community Trust is a local community based charity providing a diverse range of support groups and activities for disadvantaged families, operating out of a local church hall. Over 5 years, we have developed as an effective provider of programmes for local communities responding to social, developmental and economic needs through a range of activities, which are community and voluntary-led. Our main aim is that local people, who are experiencing disadvantage, will have opportunities for social and personal development which will improve their lives as regards better mental / physical health, stronger community connections and improved skills. Current Activities – our main activities include:- • Youth Clubs for 8 – 18 year olds delivering weekly educational programmes, outdoor trips, sport, music & film programmes, career support and mentoring; • Volunteering, mentoring and training for local people providing opportunities to gain work experience, training and qualifications; • Weekly child and support sessions delivering education through play with parenting support, Special Educational Need (SEN) support, healthy eating provision and referral onto other support services for families with young children; • Sports, health and fitness for people of all ages to motivate them to stay healthy; • Music and Film workshops aimed at engaging a diverse range of local people through music and film craft; • Outreach and detached work e.g. weekly ‘street work’ engaging local youth; Government statistics using the Indices of Deprivation indicates Purfleet is in the 20% most deprived areas in England, therefore services and activities focus on strengthening our community links and local networks that help support the need to address complex socio economic challenges. Working in partnership with many other agencies we regularly seek fresh opportunities to bring new projects to the neighbourhood, bridging gaps in the local provision.
recipientOrganization.name: St Stephen's Community Trust

recipientOrganization.description: Fledglings Family Services design and source practical, affordable, good quality products and solutions to everyday problems experienced by children with physical and learning disabilities and health conditions. Our Helpline service team offer emotional support and practical help and we source, supply and design items that help children, for example, to learn to feed independently, become toilet trained, to sit, to stand, to walk, to play, to swim, to access education and to keep children safe from harm. The Helpline team is experienced at providing sensitive emotional support and parents frequently 'open up' over the phone about issues that they would be uncomfortable discussing face-to-face. As one parent said of Fledglings, "We love that there is somewhere we can find solutions to our problems rather than confused faces! You make us feel nearly normal!" Fledglings primary purpose in trading is to meet the need of the child and family at the best possible price. We focus on meeting individual need as far as it is possible. Our voluntary income and volunteer labour is what makes this possible, as these, in effect, subsidise the cost of the item. Our objectives are to: • Increase the independence, physical and mental well-being of children living with disabilities and ill-health conditions • Support children with disabilities to achieve their educational and developmental potential • Help children with disabilities and their families/carers to experience greater inclusion in all aspects of everyday life such as education, leisure, recreation and healthcare. • Inform, facilitate and empower families/carers to support their children and each other. • Help health/social care professional to better support the child patients and families/carers. • Enable low income families to access our services and products. We co-ordinate a recycling service so that families can donate or sell at low cost items in good condition that might otherwise go to landfill. Our helpline team also identify additional funding sources for low income families. What makes us unique? Businesses supplying products suitable for disabled children and adults are often only supplying one type of item and are often driven by commercial factors which do not take account of individual need. Disability charities supplying products suitable for disabled children generally do so largely as a means of raising income to support other services. Fledglings gives families the opportunity to purchase most of what they need from one source, saving time and money. “So great to be able to get so many things we need from just one place". We also keep stocks of many small inexpensive items that can make all the difference to children but are generally only available in packs. By dividing packs we give parents the chance, with minimum financial outlay, to try an individual item to test its effectiveness. Many families come back time-after-time to purchase items from us as their children grow. One of our social worker users tells us: “The thing that makes your service stand out from any other is that you understand the needs of our families and that you are willing to go the extra mile to source items and remedy individual needs which no other organisation can do!” From a home-based organisation helping local children and families we have now grown into a national charity helping over 26,000 families a year in every region of the UK (up from 23,000 last year). This growth continues. Families find us through google searches, via word of mouth and through referrals from a wide range of health, education and social care professionals including paediatricians, occupational therapists, speech therapists, GP’s, practice nurses, portage workers, social workers, disability teams, children’s centres, school SEN officers, patient groups and disability charities. Due to our origins and location we are pleased to support a larger number of people in Essex than in other parts of the UK. Currently approximately 1306 families, carers and professionals in Essex are supported by Fledglings (increasing from 952 last year) and accounting for 4.98% of all families. As a proportion of the overall running costs (projected at £411164 in 2017-2018) the cost of supporting families in Essex is approximately £20,475. A recent example of how we have helped a family in Essex is given below; X contacted us in August 2016 to see if we could offer help and advice for her son Y referred from Grove Cottage. Her son has an undiagnosed genetic abnormality, global developmental delay, hyper mobility and is non-verbal. X’s main concern is her son’s severe head banging and his sensory issues. Y has no sense of danger and a very high pain threshold and will bruise and hurt himself so badly that he has to wear a helmet 24/7.Y doesn’t sleep well and recently put his head through a wall when he got out of bed . Y will also rock obsessively, especially at meal times when he is in his high chair. This makes feeding him hard. and pulling at his mother’s hair. Fledglings provided detailed information and advice on safe options for sleeping, a safe and secure high chair that he cannot rock, a safe car seat, secure walking reins, products to help with teeth brushing, a large special needs buggy, sensory toys and solutions, and therapies that are available. We also recommended funding programmes to help towards the cost of the products, therapies and hospital visits. We made a follow up call to X in May 2017 to ask how she was getting on. Things have improved for X. More teams became involved with her family and funding has been secured for the padded room which has, in X’s words, been ‘life changing’. Y is much happier, he is sleeping through the night, he is less tired, doesn’t bang his head as much and is now much more affectionate – ‘a different little boy’. The high chair has helped Y to feed better and the changes in the family situation have been a ‘miracle’. Y is a different boy who will be attending a special school soon.
recipientOrganization.name: Fledglings Family Services

recipientOrganization.description: Oxford Hard and Hearing Centre helps over 400 people each year in Oxfordshire to manage the effects of hearing loss. Our services include: - Communication Assistance: providing British Sign Language (BSL) interpreters. - Community Outreach and Support: to build confidence. - Social Groups: our Coffee Mornings, Deaf Clubs and Hard of Hearing Clubs bring together people with a hearing loss so they can meet other people who understand what they are going through. - Training: BSL Courses, Lip Reading Courses and Deaf Awareness training for local businesses. - Equipment: we provide advice regarding equipment to combat the effects of hearing loss. This includes amplified telephones, personal listeners to help hear the TV or flashing smoke alarms. - Youth Services: organising educational and fun activities to bring together children living with a hearing loss. - Information and Advice: a helpline to reassure those living with a hearing loss and their loved ones. We also offer practical leaflets and factsheets about managing a hearing loss. - Advocacy: enabling deaf people to understand their rights. - Volunteering We want to ensure we have a society in which deaf and hard of hearing people enjoy equal participation and access without barriers or prejudice.
recipientOrganization.name: Oxford Deaf and Hard of Hearing Centre

grants.description: Our project is aimed at giving 10 deaf and hard of hearing young people the skills and confidence they need to succeed into employment, while also engaging them with the wider community and breaking down communication barriers and stereotypes. The Centre is celebrating its 60th Anniversary this year and we will run a youth-led volunteer project to celebrate its heritage during Oxford Open Doors. This will include the young people taking part in an inter-generational project. They will be trained in oral history and be given the opportunity to interview and film older members of the local Deaf and hard of hearing communities. The volunteers will also be trained by the charity's Engagement Officer to bring their creative ideas to life by producing logos and promotional materials for the Anniversary Year. The Centre needs redecorating and some volunteers will be involved in this. The project will culminate in a event on 9th September as part of Oxford Open Doors, where the film created by the volunteers will be shown. The volunteers will also provide tours of the Centre to members of the public, developing their communication and people skills while introducing new audiences to heritage and the Deaf community.
grants.Impact Category: Improve life skills, education, employability and enterprise
grants.title: We Aren't Invisible
grants.Primary issue: Building skills and improving access to employment

recipientOrganization.description: OCVA is a membership organisation which aims to enable a diverse voluntary and community sector to flourish in Oxfordshire. We do this by providing advice, information and training, acting as advocates and representatives, and building partnerships. The key services delivered by OCVA are: the volunteer brokerage service for the City, the South of Oxfordshire and the Vale of White Horse which promotes opportunities on behalf of organisations and matches volunteers to roles in the sector, an extensive training programme delivered by OCVA staff and expert trainers which is responsive to changes and needs in the sector, the co-ordination of networks to enable collaborative working and the ability to provide individual groups with expertise and advice on funding, governance and development.

distribution.title: Grants awarded FY 2017-18

grants.description: The principle need addressed by this grant is raise the profile of volunteering in a rural community. A heightened awareness of groups and their opportunities will help organisations to grow their volunteer base; enabling them to support a greater number of service users and thus reduce disadvantage in West Oxfordshire. We will therefore spend this grant on promotional material and events designed to give a platform to the participating organisations to communicate their work. This will include: • Producing and publishing a report to document our key learning from the project. In addition to a written impact report, OCVA will be working with a team of 6 students during the week to develop a short film which documents the activity taking place in MAD Week. The aim of producing shareable material in a variety of formats is to enable this model of student volunteering to be adopted by schools across Oxfordshire. • Hosting a celebration event to showcase what the students and organisations achieve during the week. Key stakeholders from across Oxfordshire will be invited to hear about what the students have been doing and the impact it has had on them, the organisations and their service users.
grants.Impact Category: Maximise ability to strengthen community cohesion and build social capacity
grants.title: MAD Week

recipientOrganization.description: Oxford Hub is the centre for student social action in Oxford. Our aim is to support every student in Oxford to engage in social issues whilst university, empowering them to be active citizens for life. We achieve this by providing students with practical opportunities to tackle social and environmental issues and engage their peers in causes they care about. Last academic year we supported over 600 student volunteers on various student-led projects: for example, nearly 300 students tutored in local schools (with an average of 34% of pupils on FSM and 36% ESL pupils) to help local children and young people reach their academic potential; other volunteers ran free IT classes for older people to help promote connectivity and tackle loneliness; and some students ran free English Language lessons for recent migrants. In addition, we support students to incubate new volunteering project and social enterprise, such as board games to help encourage engagement in STEM subjects or a language exchange between students studying arabic and refugees. Lastly, to engage students in our activities and the issues they tackle, we held 112 events last academic year, ranging from volunteer fairs to workshops on tackling loneliness.
recipientOrganization.name: Oxford Hub

dataset.title: Grants awarded FY 2017-18

distribution.title: Grants awarded FY 2017-18

grants.description: Oxford Hub creates opportunities for social action. Through our programmes, students take part in practical volunteering, complete placements in local charities and receive support to incubate new projects. • Since 2007, we have placed roughly 6000 students in Oxford. Currently, we support 700+ student volunteers a year, and this number is growingly steadily year on year as we roll out our new digital system and grow our presence in Oxford Brookes. • We have established a sustainable business model with diversified income streams: university contracts for the specific programmes, trusts and foundations for community impact, self-generated income for innovation. • In 2011 we opened a physical space in Oxford with the Turl Street Kitchen that provides a platform for all of our activities and supports our work. • We have 10 years experience designing high quality social action programmes, with the following results: • We add capacity to 50+ local charities and other organisations. • We mobilise, train and support students to be effective changemakers. • Overall, we create services for beneficiaries that wouldn’t otherwise exist and unlock energy and resources that wouldn’t otherwise be utilised. Oxford Hub is an independent branch of national charity Student Hubs. It is currently led by Sara Fernandez, who stepped down from the parent charity in March 2017 to focus on local work. National Student Hubs HQ is now in London led by new executive director and management team. Sara reports to the local Oxford board (including representatives from the university, the community and volunteers) and works with the Oxford Hub staff team.
grants.Impact Category: Maximise ability to strengthen community cohesion and build social capacity
grants.title: Oxford Hub 2.0

recipientOrganization.description: The Abingdon Damascus Youth Project is an outcome-driven organisation that works with young people, particularly those disadvantaged by social circumstances, so that they become positive contributors within their own communities and in the process learn and practise life skills and responsibilities to enable them to stay engaged with education, employment and/or training to improve their life chances. Our objective is achieved through grass-roots, on-the-street engagement facilitated by qualified and credible youth workers who are dedicated to make change happen not only at the doorstep but also bridge the gap between home and school. We work in partnership with communities, local organisations, schools, the police and social services and doctors as required. Our success is in getting hard-to-reach young people engaged with their communities and service providers thus adding value to any existing provision.Our activities reflect the diverse needs of young people: • Street work by youth workers and volunteers; • Youth participation in community projects; • One-to-one work with the most vulnerable; • Youth led fun sports with other groups and services such as the police; • Youth Drop-in sessions; • Drugs and alcohol misuse and sexual health awareness sessions; • Healthy Relationships and internet safety.
recipientOrganization.name: Abingdon Damascus Youth Project

grants.description: Wondermind will reach new audiences not normally engaged with biomedical science by delivering a highly interactive and immersive website for children aged 8-12 and their parents, carers and teachers, which will introduce them to key neuroscience concepts in child development. They will learn about the science of brain development, inspired by works from the Tate collection and an exploration of the world presented by Lewis Carroll. The website will stimulate interest, excitement and debate about biomedical science through three main areas: 1. A series of mini-games, which will use art and ?Alice in Wonderland? themes to introduce our areas of scientific focus in a friendly and engaging way. The mini-games will be designed so that players acquire some basic information about the science of brain development through their play. 2. A set of interactive videos that link with the mini-games, but delve deeper into the science, with interviews with leading scientists and researchers. The interactive nature of the video will give the feeling of having a conversation with the expert. 3. The website itself, which holds all the content together and allows users to navigate and find information to support the scientific themes explored in the mini games and videos, linking out to further information where relevant and necessary. There will be polls and areas of the site that allow both children and adults to feed back on issues raised by the content, to encourage new ways of thinking about biomedical science. There will be lesson plans for Art and Science curricula at KS2 to support the use of Wondermind in the classroom. Wondermind will be launched with the forthcoming ?Alice in Wonderland? (http://www.tate.org.uk/liverpool/exhibitions/aliceinwonderland/default.shtm) exhibition at Tate Liverpool in November 2011.

grants.title: WONDERMIND

grants.description: A unique and innovative project to create a free package of teaching materials for primary schools to accompany JAMES, a short drama film funded by the Wellcome Trust, based on Edward Jenner's discovery of the smallpox vaccination. Led by the film's producers and the Association for Science Education, the project will bring together an exciting combination of organisations and individuals including filmmakers, science education professionals, pharmaceutical scientists, and museums to develop  and trial a package of engaging teaching resources for Key Stage 2. Focusing on biomedical science but also covering mathematics, literacy, history, art and ethics, these materials will support science- and project-based work inspired by the film and its themes. The six-week topic will give children an awareness of the importance of Jenner's discovery, an understanding of the scientific processes and methods he used, and of how they have been developed in modern medical science and vaccine tr ials. The resources will be designed to enable teachers to approach Jenner's discovery through the new 'working scientifically' area of the national curriculum science programme of study in England (with flexibility in the design to be relevant throughout the UK). Recognising that primary teachers often lack confidence in teaching science, the resources will be designed to give teachers greater confidence and experience to teach these aspects of science in the longer term. To help with this,  the project will also create and trial a range of additional professional development opportunities to support participant teachers.

grants.title: Why You'll Never Catch Smallpox - JAMES film primary school outreach.

grants.Other Applicant(s): Mrs Louise Medus-Mansell, Prof Martin Johnson
grants.description: Between 1958 and 1961, the drug thalidomide was taken by pregnant women to treat morning sickness. Its prescription resulted in the death of, or severe damage to, around 15,000 children born alive, and the loss of many more unborn babies. This project has developed from a scoping exercise - funded by a Wellcome Trust People Award between February and May 2011 - to identify historical sources relating to thalidomide. The scoping exercise revealed how little oral evidence there was. This project will help to fill the gap by employing a research assistant to gather oral histories from a selection of people impaired by thalidomide. Interviews will be recorded, transcribed and made publicly available through the inclusion of extracts in an international conference presentation, and in three public engagement events and an exhibition at the Wellcome Collection, all in 2012. Both the interviews and transcriptions will be housed in the Moving Image and Sound Collection at the Wellcome Trust where library users will be able to access them in house and remotely. In addition, we aim to publish a book based on the oral histories.

recipientOrganization.description: St Werburghs City Farm is an inner-city outdoor oasis just 1.5 miles from Bristol city centre. Situated on the border of Ashley and Lockleaze, the Farm is within or near 5 wards that fall within the 10% most disadvantaged in the UK. Since 1980, we have developed services across 4 sites to better meet the needs of disadvantaged residents. Last year, we supported 3,342 service users in 30,000 hours of activities, engaged more than 6,500 people in events/facilities and welcomed more than 53,000 visitors. With a strong reputation for high-quality services, many of our activities run at capacity. Our vision is to inspire and educate happy, healthy communities through green spaces, local food and each other. Using a 2 acre small holding, a 1 acre community garden, a 2.5 acre conservation site and 13 acres of community allotments, our mission is to offer targeted community services that equip people with knowledge, skills and confidence, and provide green sites accessible to all. Our aims are to: increase people's knowledge of where food comes from and access to locally produced food; enhance people's health and wellbeing through greater access to green spaces; and improve the capacity, confidence and cohesion of our community.
recipientOrganization.name: St Werburghs City Farm

recipientOrganization.description: Working Actively To Change Hillfields Ltd (WATCH) is a community-led Organisation established since April 1998, based in Hillfields, the most deprived neighbourhood in Coventry. “WATCH seeks to secure, and manage resources for the social, economic and environmental improvement of the area, for the benefit of people living and working in Hillfields”. The project offers a variety of support and resources and aims to support individuals facing disadvantage, social exclusion, and deprivation, BAME groups who are culturally under-represented, and persons who live in socially or linguistically isolated communities. WATCH provides access to demand-led services, and support in a friendly, culturally sensitive environment. Over the past 18 years WATCH has developed specialist skills supporting those furthest removed from the labour market to overcome barriers to employment and training, particularly individuals who are economically inactive, or long-term unemployed. Our well-known youth development project provides introduction to radio training, personal development and mentoring support to disadvantaged children and young people who are not in education, employment or training or at risk of becoming NEET. Our community radio project, HillzFM provides a voice for residents, training in all aspects of radio and media, work experience placements and the opportunity to present a radio show.

We believe that everyone should have the opportunity to experience group music-making without any barriers. Our strategic objectives are: - To deliver high quality musical opportunities for Early Years, Young People and Community Groups. - To use music as a tool where needed to promote positive social, emotional and physical wellbeing. Moving forward into 2018, examples of two focus areas will be the development of creative musical opportunities for young people with special educational needs and disabilities in and around the Somer Valley area as well as developing a project to support group interaction and communication in partnership with Action on Hearing Loss. Creative composition workshops with SWALLOW Youth Club for their SWALLOW Tales Two project. Creative composition project with Crowdys Hill School (SEND) Taster sessions with SEND Adults from both Action on Hearing Loss and Wiltshire and Swindon Users Network.

recipientOrganization.description: Cintre is a registered charity established in 1977. We have over 35 years’ experience of providing high quality residential care, outreach and supported living services for young people and adults with learning disabilities and other complex needs in a structured and therapeutic environment. Cintre’s aim is to provide the individual with independence in order to participate in society. This is achieved by: - Offering high quality support services; - Enabling individuals’ choices and involvement with their community; - Providing bespoke packages for individuals; - Making the transition into independence seamless; - Ensuring that staff teams are committed and professional. The individuals we offer support to are aged 18 years upwards and have been diagnosed with varying learning disabilities. These can include Asperger’s Syndrome and other autistic spectrum disorders, Fragile X Syndrome, Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD), Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (OCD), challenging behaviours, drug and alcohol misuse, Tourette's Syndrome, and sexual and behavioural issues. All service users have their own care and development programme designed to help them to achieve independent living within three to five years. Programmes can include college courses, day care, daily living skills, social activities and activities such as arts, crafts and DIY.

recipientOrganization.description: Founded in 2004, Access Sport is a registered charity with 18 full-time employees and 13 trustees, meeting five times per-annum. We are an award-winning charity that transforms lives through the power of sport. We do this by building thriving community-sports-clubs led by inspirational volunteers. These clubs provide life-changing opportunities for hard to reach young people whilst creating a positive and permanent resource within the community. We help the clubs to be self-sustaining, to grow, and to ensure they meet the varied needs of young people in their area. We carry out this work because the number of children and young people engaged in sport in the UK today is in significant decline and one-third of UK-children are now classified as overweight. All too often it is the poorest communities which are most affected.

recipientOrganization.description: BF provides a high quality, professional psychotherapy and counselling service for individuals, children and families. The key aims are to: - Provide counselling and psychotherapy services to those who would not easily have access to them. - Encourage understanding of the emotional barriers to healthy living, through consultation with professionals and organisations working with emotional vulnerability - Demonstrate the effectiveness of the service through monitoring and evaluation, to inform and educate policy and service development - Contribute to public understanding through training and public conferences on emotional aspects of individual, organisational and social health. There are two main strand to the work: a fee- paying service and a free to service user, mental health service called Bridge in Schools (BIS), funded by contracts with schools and voluntary donations. BIS is our core charitable work. This year Bristol schools face real term budget cuts of between 10-15% of total budget, in addition to other pressures - growing pupil numbers and increasing mental health challenges in schools are resulting in a growing need for our work.

recipientOrganization.name: Maze Cares
recipientOrganization.description: Maze Cares provides a welcoming and friendly environment for parent and carers of children with special needs to meet for social interaction, friendship, support, and advice. Through the MAZE Course, which runs for 12 weeks, taking up to 30 parents per course, we help parents better understand and meet the needs of their children. In addition, we offer other support services including monthly coffee mornings, events, speakers, activities, and workshops. Additionally, Maze Cares collaborates with other organisations, voluntary and community sector partners, acting as a signpost to other relevant support, advice and advocacy services. The MAZE Course is a unique approach which aims to develop parent’s knowledge and skills to positively parent their children with disabilities/additional need, such as learning difficulty, autism, ADHD and many other additional needs (SEN/AEN). This work aims to improve family relationships, build social networks of parents and reduce social isolation. The MAZE also aims to empower parents to work towards improving educational outcomes, leisure, and community access opportunities and improving life chances for their children with additional needs. Our funding proposal is for the 12 months from September 2017 to September 2018. Our service users are the parents and carers of children with additional needs. This may be a learning difficulty, physical disability, autism, ADHD, cerebral palsy or any other additional or special need. We have worked with parents of children with a wide range of difficulties. Many parents do not have sufficient knowledge about their child's condition and are not provided with this information on diagnosis. They are often socially isolated because of their child's difficulties, which commonly include challenging behaviour and they also struggle to access appropriate activities out of school hours. These families experience further difficulties with accessing the appropriate education and support for their child, which can result in school exclusions or tribunals. Additionally, the families face difficulties in accessing services such as O/T, speech therapy or short breaks/services through Social Care and also face very restricted leisure opportunities. When parents better understand the additional needs their child has, they are better equipped to raise them. This increased understanding leads to happier parents, happier children and happier siblings, who enjoy a calmer more stable home life, and as a result experience better physical and mental well-being. This is consistently reflected in the feedback we gather at the end of each course. We also hear from parents that after the course they feel empowered by the information and knowledge they have gained. Here’s what our parents have to say about it: “My life changed. I was lost and I didn’t know what to do. After Maze I have the tools that I need to help myself and my child. My child is happier. Less arguments in my household. Siblings are happy and not fighting.” “My son has noticed positive changes to his and my relationship as a result of alterations to our lifestyle…I’ve learned so many positive strategies from Sue and other guests and attendees to use at home, and feel very supported.” “[I have] a better understanding of how my daughter thinks, giving me methods to deal with challenging situations…we’re a lot happier.” “It helped me understand my daughter more… I see people I can relate with and felt I am not alone. This session is making me strong….best course I have ever done for my daughter and myself.” “I feel better able to communicate with my child confidently.” We have a hundreds of feedback forms filled with comments like this and 99.6% of parents highly recommend the MAZE. Benefits generated by the Maze Approach include: * Improved family relationships. * Calmer households and families. * Improved understanding and use of positive strategies * Reduced social isolation as our attendees establish a peer support network. * Improved educational provision as parents & carers are more able to advocate for their child, and work with education professionals to ensure their needs are met. * More positive engagement between professionals (including healthcare) and parents. * Improved educational outcomes – better attendance and reduction in exclusions. * Reduced reliance on mental health services for both parents and children – we have consistent feedback from parents that they feel stronger, more resilient and better supported * Access to ongoing support for an unlimited amount of time and access to this ensures constant progress and stability for our families. To create a sustainable funding model, we would like to trial a year of requesting parental contributions, and analyse: * how many parents are able to make the contribution. * what impact this model has on the number of places requested. * what impact this model has on the % of sessions attended by parents. In order to run this trial we first need: * To create efficient and sustainable administrative systems to cope with the volume of referrals we are handling (pediatricians, EWMHS, Barnardos and other local family support workers refer to us). To date we have supported 3000 families). * To create systems to measure the social impact and outcomes for families, not just over the 12-week duration of the course but in the months following. * To create systems that enable us to manage data responsibly. And, as we are unsure of how much income will be generated, we need to have the basic venue, refreshment and materials costs covered for the two core Colchester programs that we offer. Any revenue generated from the parental contribution would be used to fund a third Colchester program to help reduce our waiting lists.

recipientOrganization.description: IPSEA’s Aim: To enable children and young people with special educational needs and disabilities to maximise their educational potential. Objectives: 1)To help 50% more people 2) To increase capacity in the volunteer workforce by 50% 3) To double current level of unrestricted income 4) To ensure that no relevant government initiative takes place without IPSEA input IPSEA aims to help parents to support their children and young people with special educational needs and/or disabilities (SEND) to obtain appropriate education and training that is a legal requirement under the Children and Family Act 2014. We also advise local and national government on legislation, policies and implementation relating to SEN. We provide support and advice to parents/carers of children and young people with SEND. All our advice and support is delivered by our dedicated volunteers, supported by a small staff team. IPSEA is a user-led organisation. Many of our volunteers, staff, members and trustees are parents/carers of children or young people with SEND. We have developed a website with a raft of resources that are downloadable free for parents. This is complemented by a separate advice line which provides legally based information and next step advice on any educational issues that is a result of the child’s or young persons SEND. The tribunal helpline gives next step advice on appeals and disability discrimination claims to the SEND Tribunal, this is also the gateway to our Tribunal Support Service where a referral can be made for more extensive support from a volunteer. Making a SEND tribunal appeal is very complicated. The appeal system involves vast amounts of paperwork, evidence has to be gathered from professional witnesses & there is a complex timetable with multiple deadlines. There is no Legal Aid for representation at hearings. There is limited Legal Aid to assist with preparing a case. Lawyers charge up to £10,000 to prepare & represent these tribunal cases. Meanwhile the Local Authorities against whom these appeals are registered have teams of lawyers to prepare their case and representing them at the tribunal hearing. IPSEA's unique Tribunal Support Service addresses this need - free of charge. IPSEA has highly trained volunteers who act as individual caseworkers for SEND Tribunal appeals. These Tribunal Support volunteers complete our accredited legally-based tribunal training in order to provide individual casework support and advocacy for children throughout their tribunal appeal. Access to this specialised service is only available via our Tribunal Helpline. Volunteers with experience of supporting appeals on behalf of children to the SEND Tribunal cover this specialist helpline, using their accredited legally-based IPSEA training and casework experience to offer next-step tribunal appeal support over the telephone. If a child needs individual casework support, our Tribunal Helpline volunteers refer them to our Tribunal Support service. The criteria for this referral are based on the child's household income, the complexity of the child's appeal and whether the child's family can cope with the appeal process. This referral process allows us to offer the most support to the most disadvantaged children. We carefully match each tribunal appeal to a volunteer with the right experience. Our volunteer represents the child throughout their appeal process; managing the timetable, gathering/compiling evidence, helping with paperwork and attending the hearing to advocate for the child against the Local Authority lawyers. Our volunteers won 86% of their appeals in 2015. IPSEA also provides a wide range of training for parents, School Staff, Parent Forums, support groups and other groups and organisations in order to empower users with information and increase their confidence.We developed unique training on the SEND reforms. We have already trained 2,000 people from other organisations this year. We work in partnership with the National Parent Partnership Network (now IASS), training their staff on the SEND reforms. Where we are involved in tribunals our legal team write briefings and resources in order to disseminate and share the learning. A further innovative aspect of our organisation is our campaigning and policy work and our members have been key is shaping both policy and law.
recipientOrganization.name: IPSEA (Independent Parental Special Education Advice)

recipientOrganization.description: We are an active and vibrant parent led independent charity, set up in 1996, following extensive research, committed to helping improve the lives of families of children/young people (0-25) with any Special Educational Need or Disability (SEND) across Essex, including those with physical and/or sensory impairments, learning difficulties, mental health issues and emotional/behavioural problems of an enduring nature. Current highly successful and valued activities include Family Support Advisers working across Essex providing information, advice, emotional and practical support, addressing a wide range of issues, achieving positive outcomes improving health, social, emotional and economic well-being, strengthening and building resilience, enhancing stability and improving quality of life for the whole family. Our Siblings Support Group (brothers and sisters aged 8+, who are young carers) providing opportunities for them to have some time away from the family group to enjoy their childhood/meet others with similar experiences. Our Family Saturday Activity Club providing fun activities with health benefits for the whole family. We also organise 'Drop-ins'/respite opportunities, Parenting and learning opportunities, family events, regular e-bulletins, website, and Face-book presence.

recipientOrganization.description: We aim to enhance lives by providing bespoke support for 11-25 year olds to overcome day to day difficulties. This is achieved by boosting confidence by helping young people identify their strengths and develop strategies, through opportunities for them to feel more confident and empowered. Our Drop-in’s provide 1-1 sessions with a Support Worker allowing a young person to explore their difficulties and feelings, in a safe environment. Through these sessions we help them to improve their communication with peers, families and agencies so they are more resilient. By learning skills that will help them to problem solve their issues in the future more positively. By identifying their qualities, we progress onto a range of youth led group activities, this helps them to hone in on their often, hidden talents. Current projects include: Harwich Inspired Youth Action (HIYA)for 11-18 years-Young People making a difference to their community. Wildlife Project-for 11-25 years- Young People involved in activities that support local wildlife Volunteer Programme-for 18-25 years-an opportunity to develop their knowledge and practical skills. Each of the above provides a base for Young People to develop their ideas and gives them the opportunity to try new things.

grants.description: DeafHope is the UK's only, award-winning, specialist service for Deaf female survivors of domestic abuse and violence, and their children. It is delivered by Deaf women for Deaf women, and is vastly more cost-effective than using Interpreters. The service also provides support to Deaf men, through advice and supported signposting. Caseworkers use British Sign Language and other international sign languages. The service is regularly assessed as 'outstanding' by London Councils' RAG rating.   DeafHope London will deliver: o Specialist D/deaf referral for all London Borough Officers and IDVAs  o IDVA and outreach 1-2-1 support for deaf women and young people o Prevention/early intervention workshops in schools/youth groups to boys and girls (Young DeafHope) o Psychological Therapy for clients with complex needs, anxiety and/or depression o Survivors' Workshops - Deaf-led support groups o British Sign Language (BSL) and other accessible information about domestic abuse for Deaf community  o Deaf awareness training/support for London Borough Officers and mainstream domestic violence providers  This will achieve all specification outcomes:  o Reduced levels/ repeat victimisation of sexual and domestic violence o Improves wellbeing o Increases safety and independence  o London Borough Officers and IDVAs have a quality Deaf referral route o Multi-agency providers have a better understanding of how to meet Deaf access    o Supports BAMER, LGBT and Multiple Complex Needs Deaf women
grants.title: DeafHope London

grants.recipientLocation: E05010884 Woodhouse Ward E08000019 Yorkshire and the Humber Sheffield District

recipientOrganization.description: The Issue: The UK has one of the worst rates for social mobility in the developed world. Almost 4 million children in the UK today are living in low-income households. These young people face many barriers beyond their control throughout their early lives that have a significant impact on their future. For example, young people from low-income homes with similar GCSEs to their better-off classmates are one third more likely to drop out of education at 16, and for the ones that do continue they are 30% less likely to study A-levels that could get them into a top university. All of this means that just one out of every eight young people from low-income backgrounds go on to become a high-income earner later in life. And even for those that do fulfil their potential; get good qualifications and progress into professional careers, they are paid an average of £6,800 less per year than their colleagues from more affluent families. This is what low social mobility means for real people, every day. Communities across the UK, not just in the north, are being left behind. Not only is it not fair, it is also an incredible waste of talent and ability. Furthermore, low social mobility is estimated to cost the UK economy up to £140bn per year by 2050. Villiers Park Educational Trust is a national charity working to improve social mobility in the UK by supporting less advantaged high potential young people to succeed in education and careers. We do this by equipping these young people with essential skills and providing greater access to opportunities. Everything we do is about supporting young people to build these core skills, so that they can thrive throughout their education and careers. Each year we directly work with almost 2000 students through our range of programmes. Our regionally based Scholars Programme is an unprecedented four-year programme for participating students, providing mentoring, skills workshops, university and career interactions, and residential visits designed to build on subject specific knowledge and promote further education. Our innovative INVOLVE awards scheme sees student-led projects delivered to secondary beneficiaries at a ratio of 5:1. This not only builds leadership and project management skills of students undertaking INVOLVE, but also passes on educational skills to the secondary beneficiaries, and helps to create a culture of learning and raised aspirations within schools. In addition, our renowned Inspiring Excellence residential programme is our longest running programme of subject specific week long courses – bringing able students from across the UK together to experience a vibrant and inspiring learning environment. The courses run throughout the year for students to study at degree level, undertake unique visits to relevant companies and organisations, and be taught by young leaders in the field. The Activity – Inspiring Excellence: Villiers Park has been running residential courses for over 50 years, and have outstanding data that evidences the impact on young people who take part. The Inspiring Excellence courses provide able students with a challenging and transformational experience that provides lasting impact. High potential A-level students from state schools stay in groups of 25 for five days to study their chosen subject at university level, and experience independent learning and staying away from home. The courses are designed to improve skills, raise aspirations and increase awareness of the range of opportunities available to help students reach their potential. Each year we run 32 courses on a wide spectrum of subjects covering science, technology, engineering, maths, English, humanities & arts. Over 800 students take part, building essential skills such as team work, resilience, leadership and independence. During these five-day subject-specific residential courses, students are introduced to the latest ideas and research, allowing them to explore challenging topics in subjects across the sciences, arts and humanities. Teamwork, research, presentation skills and creativity are important features of our courses, helping participants to develop key study and employability skills. The academic, motivational and social benefits of attending are strong, as testified by teachers, university admissions tutors, and most importantly by the students themselves. Specifically our courses set out to: • Provide an insight into university-level material by studying a wide range of exciting topics • Challenge students to stretch the limit of their abilities with a group of like-minded students in a supportive and non-competitive environment • Offer active learning experience through workshops, group discussions and presentations • Develop important skills to ensure academic success and employability This nationally acclaimed programme is listed on the UCAS application form as evidence of preparation for higher education. Furthermore, references to specific aspects of our courses within personal statements are frequently picked up on and made a focus of during university interviews. Lasting impact: 23% of all state school students, compared to 65% of all independently schooled students, progressed to the most selective universities. In contrast, last year 76% of students taking part in an Inspiring Excellence course secured a place at a leading university. Feedback is consistently good, whether five, ten or even thirty years on: “In 1983 I attended the history short course at Villiers Park, it is no exaggeration to say that it was a life changing experience. As a 16 year old from a family with no previous experience of university, at a school where no previous students had gone to university I didn’t know anyone who had applied to or gone to university. So while determined I lacked real confidence in my ability to apply and be successful and was really worried about “fitting in” and being good enough should I be successful. The support, insight and confidence that course gave me I firmly believe was critical to achieving an unexpected 5 offers from 5 Russell Group schools – having been encouraged by my head teacher to focus on polytechnics as a more achievable goal.” – Julie, History 1983, now Senior VP at an international organisation.
recipientOrganization.name: Villiers Park Educational Trust
