recipientOrganization.description: Southside aims to ensure that children, young people and adults with multiple and complex difficulties in Bath and North East Somerset access the care and support they need, so their families enjoy the safety, experiences and opportunities they deserve. Southside works with people whose lives have been damaged by violence, abuse and neglect. More than two thirds of those we support have been victims of domestic abuse, causing emotional and mental ill-health, social isolation, homelessness and debt. We provide attachment-based whole family support to meet needs of the children, young people and adults involving: • assessment, multi-agency planning, packages of support which include home-based, therapeutically focused parenting support • domestic violence advice and advocacy for parents • specialist support for young victims • young people led volunteering and advocacy (Young Advocates) • counselling • peer support within community hub groups with children’s play • therapeutic play for children • help to access services to tackle debt, substance abuse, mental health, physical well-being, social support • help to access education and training For over twenty years, Southside has been ‘standing behind’ people when they need us, in a non-judgemental, compassionate and encouraging way. We have deep roots in local communities and are known and trusted.
recipientOrganization.name: Southside Family Project

recipientOrganization.description: Working Actively To Change Hillfields Ltd (WATCH) is a community-led Organisation established since April 1998, based in Hillfields, the most deprived neighbourhood in Coventry. “WATCH seeks to secure, and manage resources for the social, economic and environmental improvement of the area, for the benefit of people living and working in Hillfields”. The project offers a variety of support and resources and aims to support individuals facing disadvantage, social exclusion, and deprivation, BAME groups who are culturally under-represented, and persons who live in socially or linguistically isolated communities. WATCH provides access to demand-led services, and support in a friendly, culturally sensitive environment. Over the past 18 years WATCH has developed specialist skills supporting those furthest removed from the labour market to overcome barriers to employment and training, particularly individuals who are economically inactive, or long-term unemployed. Our well-known youth development project provides introduction to radio training, personal development and mentoring support to disadvantaged children and young people who are not in education, employment or training or at risk of becoming NEET. Our community radio project, HillzFM provides a voice for residents, training in all aspects of radio and media, work experience placements and the opportunity to present a radio show.

recipientOrganization.description: The Bath Deaf Club opens one evening a month.It is a Deaf-led organisation aiming to reduce isolation amongst Deaf BSL-users. We have a Christmas meal and coach trips to places of interest and other Deaf Clubs - these promote inclusion, (Deaf & hearing members and their partners/families together), support independence & promote health & wellbeing..Most of our activities are self-funded, each member paying to participate, and we have a monthly raffle to raise funds. We provide informative talks with BSL Interpreters eg wellbeing services for BSL-users, fire prevention. We also work with other Deaf organisations and professionals working with Deaf people and can give out information to our members (eg re BSL-interpreted events at Bristol/Bath Museums) and answer queries from members of the public/Deaf professionals/organisations. We also welcome hearing people who are learning BSL and wish to practise/improve their signing skills and their knowledge of Deaf culture. We provide the opportunity for Trainee Interpreters to observe and co-work with Registered Interpreters.

Travelling Lights mission is to enhance the lives of children and young people through
theatre. We have been making outstanding theatre for and with children and young
people for over 30 years, engaging children as young as 6 months. Through making
high quality professional shows we aim to inspire young people's thinking, engage their
emotions and fire their imaginations. We tour our professional productions nationally and internationally and last year we reached audiences of over 14,000 children and their families.
Travelling Light also has a thriving participation programme. Based in the heart of

Last year we delivered over 6,000 experiences for children and young people aged 0-25, providing a safe and welcoming space for them to express themselves through theatre.

recipientOrganization.description: NESS is a local charity based in Aberdeen that supports around 5,500 visually and hearing impaired people of all ages, their families and carers across Grampian, Moray and more recently Angus and Tayside. NESS exists to help people overcome the potentially devastating practical and emotional effects of their serious sensory loss.  We achieve this by providing a range of high quality services, both statutory and non-statutory to help the people we support lead more independent lives.  Over the years we have identified and developed a range of ‘added value’ services funded from charitable income.  These include CIS (Connect, Inform and Support) a service for socially isolated older people, a support project for children and young people and an employment service offering jobseeker and in-work support.  We also provide an ICT suite and offer a range of technology-awareness skills and training courses, run a hospital information service and offer transcription services.

recipientOrganization.description: Please note that in June 2014, KEEN became a charitable incorporated organisation with registered charity number 1157084. Prior to that, we operated under the name K.E.E.N (Kid's Enjoy Exercise Now), registered charity number 299786. Since this transition, our provision to our disabled service users has remained unchanged. KEEN provides free sporting and social activities for children and young adults with wide ranging needs and disabilities. We aim to provide one-to-one support to our service users (our "Athletes") from dedicated volunteers (our "Coaches"), who are largely students from Oxford's two universities. We run four different sessions, which take place each week of Oxford University term time. These include a multi-sports club for ages 4 - 25 (called AllSorts), two social clubs for teenagers and adults respectively (KEEN teens and GrEAT) as well as a creative session aimed at primary school age children (Zig-Zag). In additional to these, KEEN runs various one-off holiday activities, known as "KEEN+", which include swimming, pantomime visits, day-trips and more. KEEN gives disabled young people from Oxfordshire the opportunity to take part in a variety of activities that are similar to those enjoyed by their able bodied peers, yet may otherwise be unavailable to them. Our high level of support means that we can cater to a wide range of needs and disabilities, and tailor activities such that everyone can get involved. By linking local disabled young people with volunteers of a similar age, we provide a safe, social environment where our Athletes can develop their confidence and skills.

recipientOrganization.description: Founded in 2004, Access Sport is a registered charity with 18 full-time employees and 13 trustees, meeting five times per-annum. We are an award-winning charity that transforms lives through the power of sport. We do this by building thriving community-sports-clubs led by inspirational volunteers. These clubs provide life-changing opportunities for hard to reach young people whilst creating a positive and permanent resource within the community. We help the clubs to be self-sustaining, to grow, and to ensure they meet the varied needs of young people in their area. We carry out this work because the number of children and young people engaged in sport in the UK today is in significant decline and one-third of UK-children are now classified as overweight. All too often it is the poorest communities which are most affected.

recipientOrganization.description: BF provides a high quality, professional psychotherapy and counselling service for individuals, children and families. The key aims are to: - Provide counselling and psychotherapy services to those who would not easily have access to them. - Encourage understanding of the emotional barriers to healthy living, through consultation with professionals and organisations working with emotional vulnerability - Demonstrate the effectiveness of the service through monitoring and evaluation, to inform and educate policy and service development - Contribute to public understanding through training and public conferences on emotional aspects of individual, organisational and social health. There are two main strand to the work: a fee- paying service and a free to service user, mental health service called Bridge in Schools (BIS), funded by contracts with schools and voluntary donations. BIS is our core charitable work. This year Bristol schools face real term budget cuts of between 10-15% of total budget, in addition to other pressures - growing pupil numbers and increasing mental health challenges in schools are resulting in a growing need for our work.

recipientOrganization.description: At OXPIP we help parents and their babies build close and loving relationships from the start of life. For 18 years we have provided intensive therapeutic support to parents and their babies from conception to two years old as well as training and consultation for practitioners and professionals. OXPIP also works with policy makers and the general public to build awareness, support and capacity for parent infant attachment and infant mental health. Our aim is to redress disadvantage and deprivation that adversely affect development at the start of a child's life. A substantial body of neuro scientific evidence supports OXPIP's work, indicating that the origins of many social and mental health problems lie in infancy and childhood, and are strongly influenced by the quality of the parent infant relationship. Children lacking experience of loving relationships and strong attachments in the first two years of life are more likely to struggle to establish secure or happy relationships as they grow. Inconsistent and neglectful or abusive care in infancy is known to impact directly on brain development, affecting the individual's ability to regulate emotions properly. We have worked in Oxfordshire for 18 years and started a small project in Reading two years ago. We work in six Childrens' centres in Oxfordshire (funding sadly ending in December 2016 due to recent cuts). We have had military projects at Dalton, Benson and Brize Norton and are currently funded in Brize Norton. We have an Asian Outreach project in the city centre and a rural outreach project in West Oxfordshire. We also provide training to early years staff and future parent infant therapists.
recipientOrganization.name: Oxford Parent Infant Project (OXPIP)

grants.Other Applicant(s): Prof Kate Pickett, Prof Caroline Relton, Dr Roger Parslow, Dr Susan Ring, Prof Neil Small, Dr Rosemary McEachan, Prof John Wright
grants.description: We will enhance the Born in Bradford (BiB) resource and make it accessible. Between 2007-2011 information on a wide range of characteristics were collected from 12,453 women who experienced 13,776 pregnancies (recruited at ~28 weeks), their babies (13,818) and partners (3,448). Mothers were assessed and completed an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT). Infants had detailed anthropometric assessments at birth and postnatally to five years. Maternal and cord blood samples have been stored and DNA e xtracted for ~10,000 mothers and ~10,000 children. There are over 250,000 biological samples. BiB is unique: (i) over half of the families are of South Asian origin, predominantly Pakistani, providing a relatively homogenous group with a high prevalence of consanguinity and predisposition to cardiometabolic disease; (ii) it is the largest study with pregnancy OGTT, postnatal anthropometry and recently funded (to be collected) genome-wide data on mothers and offspring; (iii) it was established  with input from health practitioners, the public and academics to address key research needs. Objectives are to develop BiB by: 1. Producing an effective biobank 2. Linking participants to health and education data 3. Developing systems to make all existing and newly collected data available to the scientific community 4. Enhancing public engagement

grants.description: Each year in the UK there are approximately 400 new cases of childhood ALL and 30 cases of relapsed ALL. It is really important if this treatment is to be successful to use a marker, known as Minimal Residual Disease (MRD) that indicates risk so that the treatment can be tailored to each child.  Although extremely helpful, the current method of measuring MRD is time consuming, expensive, complicated and doesn’t give a result for all children.A team led by Dr John Moppett of University Hospitals Bristol NHS Foundation Trust is developing a new method that will enable delivery of a cheaper, faster and more sensitive test, involving more patients, whilst also enabling further understanding of why children with the disease sometimes relapse.

grants.description: Stereo vision, often called 3D vision, is the ability to use both eyes together to see depth. Clinicians use specialised vision tests, called stereotests, to measure patients’ 3D vision in disorders like squint. This helps them monitor progress, assess whether treatment is helping, and can guide decisions like when to operate.However, existing stereotests are not very reliable. Young children may not understand the test or be willing to cooperate, e.g. by wearing 3D glasses. This limits the usefulness of current stereotests. Recently, the first glasses-free 3D tablet computers have come on the market. A team led by Dr Jenny Read at Newcastle University wants to use these to produce a better stereotest. For children, the stereotest will be embedded in a fun, colourful game. Patients will give their answers by touching the screen. The device will use these responses to interactively adapt the test for that particular patient, customising it for each individual. The device will monitor patients while they do the test and automatically correct for any changes in viewing distance. As a result, it will provide clinicians with more accurate data on 3D vision, especially in small children. This will help healthcare professionals to track the progress of treatment and make the best clinical decisions.

grants.description: We wish to apply the discoveries, creative methods, and learning from our Wellcome-supported R&D project 'Uluzuzulalia' to develop and deliver innovative vocal artwork for children aged 6-11. We will continue to put audience experience at the core of sensual, adventurous and refined creative experiments with the audience's own vivacious voices. We will draw from compositional approaches and aesthetic impulses that plunder experimental music, fringe theatre & performance, digital interactivity, and design-led immersive performance to celebrate vocal individuality and daring, and thereby expand the boundaries of vocal art for children. The project has three strands. One develops an iPad app, 'Voice Bubbles', whose vibrant and sensual visual design and sonic content will draw child and family users into interactive vocal creavity, allowing them to record, 'paint' with, organise, play back, and discover improvisatory delight in their body's extended vocal sound. The second is a pe rformerless installation, 'Voice Trunk', whose layered, cork-bark exterior will open into a sound-light-and-texture wonderworld, inside which audience are enticed into extending and creatively manipulating their audiovisual worlds using vocal play as source material. Alongside the above, we wish to refine and improve the content, design, and audience engagement strategies for the original piece, 'Uluzuzulalia', and expand its reach via a national tour. These outcomes, supported by the pr oject web site, will create and disseminate an original suite of interactive works which stimulate reflection on the human vocal body's nature, and its relationship with sensation and emotion, celebrating our vocal anatomies' unique, creative individualities.

grants.description: This community art project, led by Cheryl James, is a collaboration between University College London (UCL), the Royal Free Hampstead NHS Trust (RFH) and South Harringay Junior School (SHJS). It will produce a model for engagement of parents and children with biomedical science. Taking the normal microbial flora of their own bodies as the starting point, participants will develop art works exploring the relationship between the human host and the 'good' and 'bad' bacteria we are told of through the mass media and advertising. The work will be exhibited in schools and local venues, to promote the involvement of further partners.

recipientOrganization.name: London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine

grants.description: The prevalence of allergic disease has increased dramatically over the past few decades in industrialized countries and is increasing at an alarming rate in urban centres in the non-industrialized world, but prevalence remains low in rural areas. There is strong evidence for an inverse relationship between allergy risk and geohelminth prevalence, and this has led to the suggestion that endemic geohelminth infection in rural areas may protect against allergic disease. Programmes for the control of geohelminth infections are now a widely implemented strategy targeted at school-age children. The candidate proposes to investigate the impact of long-term treatment with the broad-spectrum anthelmintic drug, ivermectin, on the risk of atopy and allergic disease in school age children living in rural communities in Esmeraldas Province in Ecuador. Semi-annual/annual treatments with ivermectin have been used for the past 10 years to control onchocerciasis in endemic communities in Esmeraldas Province in Ecuador, and the candidate will compare the prevalence of atopy and allergy in 40 rural communities that have received ivermectin with 40 comparable communities that have not received the intervention. The data will provide also the opportunity to examine individual versus community-level risk factors for allergic disease in the rural Tropics.

grants.description: MLW has established a highly productive dialogue between researchers and the public on their perceptions of medical research through Community Advisory Groups in rural communities and science cafés in urban Blantyre. An MLW exhibition with outreach is a vital next step in the provision of educational resources that reach study participant communities and school children learning science. This project will create a participative exhibition that explores research through the eyes of the researcher, doctor, patient and participant. We will promote knowledge of MLW research and awareness of science in general. We will provide a platform for the dissemination of research findings and the creation of both fixed and mobile educational resources, which address both health and disease The overall project consists of 3 components: planning exhibits and assessing interpretive methods (phase I); design of test exhibits (phase II); and implementation of a permanent exhibit (phase III). Support is requested for phases I+II which aim to, 1. Assess and document concepts and designs of highly successful medical science museums in South Africa (Adler Museum); London (Wellcome Collection); and Leeds (Thackray Museum) 2. Analyse potential audience's knowledge of medical research and find best interpretive methods for the audience 3. Construct and test prototype exhibits in schools and participant communities. 4. Formulate evaluation tools to assess the impact of prototype exhibits. This project will generate debate on the value of medical research to Malawian society. The project will be based at MLW in Blantyre and will be led by MLW's Science Communication Officer.

recipientOrganization.description: Bristol Music Trust (BMT) aims to provide creative and inspirational musical experiences for the people of Bristol and the South West through performance, music-making, education and talent development. BMT runs Bristol's iconic Colston Hall which presents a diverse programme of music, attracting 300,000 people per year. BMT also manages Bristol Plays Music (BPM), the only official Department for Education music education hub in the UK based in a professional performance setting. BPM, accounting for just 23.67% of BMT’s total expenditure, is fully embedded within the community and delivers the National Plan for Music Education and other music activities throughout schools and communities in Bristol reaching over 30,000 children in 130 schools, special schools, youth groups and music centres per year. In 2017, BPM was awarded the Major Award at the Music Teacher Awards for Excellence - the ‘Oscars’ of the music education world. BPM has led a comprehensive review of music education provision and has identified a significant lack of opportunities available to Children in Care, particularly in Southmead and Filwood (Knowle West). Our Hope Creative music sessions address this through a year-long programme of music-making for young people in care in these two areas of Bristol.

recipientOrganization.description: Bath Area Play Project is an inclusive charity which aims to promote and facilitate opportunities for children and young people to play and participate in positive activities. This support is completed through nurture groups which are provided at local schools with the aim to increase self-confidence and the ability to build relationships and play coherently with other children. Family Play hubs are also provided which work with families experiencing challenging times in order to encourage parents to work alongside their children and build relationships through play with the focus on practicing and improving parenting tools and whole family play. Bath Area Play Project employ staff and have volunteers who are supported through access to training, to be effective positive role models for the children and families we support. Staff and volunteers receive regualr support and supervision, encouraging reflective practice and expected to understand outcomes we are focused on to support cahnge for children and families. All of our services are led by paid staff however we support volunteers to work alongside staff, enabking them to gain experience and confidence in working with children and young people.
recipientOrganization.name: Bath Area Play Project

recipientOrganization.description: BF provides a high quality, professional psychotherapy and counselling service for individuals, children and families. The key aims are to: - Provide counselling and psychotherapy services to those who would not easily have access to them. - Encourage understanding of the emotional barriers to healthy living, through consultation with professionals and organisations working with emotional vulnerability - Demonstrate the effectiveness of the service through monitoring and evaluation, to inform and educate policy and service development - Contribute to public understanding through training and public conferences on emotional aspects of individual, organisational and social health. There are two main strand to the work: a fee- paying service and a free to service user, mental health service called Bridge in Schools (BIS), funded by contracts with schools and voluntary donations. BIS is our core charitable work. This year Bristol schools face real term budget cuts of between 10-15% of total budget, in addition to other pressures - growing pupil numbers and increasing mental health challenges in schools are resulting in a growing need for our work.
recipientOrganization.name: Bridge Foundation

recipientOrganization.description: “Yellow Submarine Holidays” provides supported holidays and activities for people with learning disabilities (PWLD). It operates with three aims: 1/ to offer PWLD choice in holiday options and day-trips at affordable (/subsidised) prices; 2/ to provide respite for those who care for PWLD; 3/ to give young people training and volunteering opportunities to support this vulnerable group on our outings both for the immediate gain of assisting positively and so they are better equipped to promote community cohesion. In 2009, Yellow Submarine partnered with two day centres and a local authority and four holidays with 19 PWLD (and their carers who gained respite) benefitting. The trips that have taken place so far have been very popular and successful both with the ‘service users’, their carers and the volunteers who helped. Video feedback can be viewed on our site, with carers saying the holidays have helped increase confidence, create new friendships, and give a welcome break! Yellow Submarine believes people with learning disabilities deserve to live life to the full. We are a small award-winning charity which prides itself on giving some of the most disadvantaged people in Oxfordshire confidence, independence and a sense of self-worth. For children (aged 11-18) living in Oxfordshire we run an extensive programme in the school holidays. For adults (18+) we run residential holidays, work experience & training and a weekly social club. Case study published on website Nov 2014, original stored here: Y:\NEW FILESTORE 2011\7 MARKETING, COMMS & CAMPAIGNS\CASE STUDIES\Grant stories
recipientOrganization.name: Yellow Submarine

recipientOrganization.description: Bookfeast is an Oxfordshire charity dedicated to developing the habit of reading with all its attendant benefits; social, educational and emotional. We create projects and social experiences that encourage children and adults to enjoy and be able to talk about reading, and make the link between reading and writing. We are meeting our aims by running an annual literary Festival for 2000 county primary school children, based at the Ashmolean, the Pitt Rivers and the Oxford Museum of Natural History every May, and 44 book groups led by our trained volunteers. 24 of these are ‘Lunchboox Clubs’ in primary schools and 20 are ‘TeaBooks Groups’ for older people, in a variety of settings: day care centres, residential homes, libraries and sheltered accommodation.

recipientOrganization.description:
Travelling Lights mission is to enhance the lives of children and young people through
theatre. We have been making outstanding theatre for and with children and young
people for over 30 years, engaging children as young as 6 months. Through making
high quality professional shows we aim to inspire young people's thinking, engage their
emotions and fire their imaginations. We tour our professional productions nationally and internationally and last year we reached audiences of over 14,000 children and their families.
Travelling Light also has a thriving participation programme. Based in the heart of
Barton Hill in Bristol, we engage with children, young people and their families in our
local area. Services include family theatre sessions, weekly youth theatre groups,
youth-led performance projects and career development opportunities. We currently engage 60 young people (aged 4-21) per week through these services, with over 50% from our local BS5 postcode.
Our schools programme reaches children across Bristol, enabling them to embrace their creativity, take ownership of their work and gain practical experience of making theatre. Last year we delivered over 6,000 experiences for children and young people aged 0-25, providing a safe and welcoming space for them to express themselves through theatre.
recipientOrganization.name: Travelling Light Theatre Company

recipientOrganization.description: Barrow Farm is a specially equipped riding centre in Mid Essex. Our aim is to enable people with special needs & disabilities to develop their abilities, and enrich their lives through riding. Aim: To provide the opportunity for people with special needs and/or disabilities to ride and carriage drive for the benefit of their health and well-being Objectives 1. To have a team of suitable ponies and be vigilant to their care and welfare 2. To maximise our impact on the wellbeing of disabled adults and children 3. To involve our users to identify areas for improvement and develop strategies to achieve the improvement 4. To improve our financial strength by identifying fund raising and grant making opportunities to provide a subsidised service and deliver our development plan 5. To continue to invest in, maintain and upgrade our facilities 6. To ensure that staff, trustees & volunteers undertake education and training for the benefit and advancement of our riders Riding means many things to many people and our riders are no different. Riding here can provide: - physiotherapy and exercise - a chance to learn - the opportunity to make new friends and - build self esteem and confidence All this while having fun! We also offer carriage driving, which has wheelchair access. We have about 125 riders including carriage drivers. Over the course of a year, they take part in approximately 5,000 hours of activities, comprising of lessons in our indoor riding school, ménage, outside walks along our adapted woodland path. To help our riders achieve their individual goals and improve their health and wellbeing, we offer: - the opportunity for riders to take part in our proficiency test programme, where they are awarded RDA grades - ASDAN (Award Scheme Development and Accreditation Network) - Endurance sessions, which improves riders' balance, concentration, stamina and co-ordination through the use of obstacles and extended distances within a session i.e. hacks. - the opportunity to compete in Regional & National RDA events - the opportunity to take part in musical rides - Pony Days during the school summer holidays where riders learn independence skills as well as gain a deeper knowledge of horse care and horse riding We engage with our local community and local organisations to help achieve our vision of fun, fitness, friendship, and fulfilment for all our riders.
recipientOrganization.name: Barrow Farm Riding for the Disabled

recipientOrganization.description: SOS Rape Crisis is a charity providing specialist confidential and non-judgemental support for survivors of any form of sexual violence. The aims and objectives of the organisation are: *Relieve the sickness and distress of survivors who have suffered any form of sexual violence. *Promote education and research in the subject of rape and its effects on the survivor, whether physical, medical, psychological or social. *Encourage staff and volunteers to continuously train and develop to enhance wellbeing of survivors. *Publish educative and informative material about rape. *Obtain help and support where needed through close contact with government authorities, health services and voluntary organisations. *Set up a co-ordinated group of contacts to further the charitable aims and objectives of the charity. *Raise money for the purpose of the charity on such terms and on such security as may be thought fit. *Accept donations and legacies. ACTIVITIES: The service supports victims from the communities of Southend on Sea, Castle Pont and Rochford, Essex - operating within dedicated, safe premises as well as rural outreach where necessary - the services helps survivors move forward with their lives and make appropriate choices. The specialist service provided by SOS Rape Crisis includes: *Information & Support Helpline operated by qualified sexual violence counsellors. *Support & Advocacy service providing practical support and guidance for adults on housing, benefits as well as support for adult survivors of sexual violence going through the criminal justice system. *Under 18's ISVA support service - providing advice and support for young people and families going through the criminal justice system *Face to face specialist sexual violence counselling session for young people aged 11 years upwards as well as adult counselling services for males and females. *Dedicated, specialist Under 11's therapy services for young children under the age of 11 years. *Young Persons therapeutic support group services including awareness and prevention activity as well as dealing with issues as a result of the violence such as: self esteem; self confidence; negative body image etc. *Promotional and educative service in the subject of sexual abuse and rape and its effects on survivors, working directly with schools, colleges and partners in the local area. *Therapeutic Yoga sessions - enabling survivors to relieve their thoughts and feelings through yoga. *Parent support programme. One to one counselling and/or support group work for parents or young people/children who have suffered child sexual abuse or sexual violence. Enabling them to understand behaviours and attitudes and to provide suggested coping strategies to use themselves and with their children to move forward positively. *Southend WAVE - working in partnership with range of agencies to provide women in prostitution or the sex industry opportunities to make different choices. Ultimately providing route out of prostitution. *Adult Peer support group - providing ongoing therapeutic support to women who have suffered sexual violence and/or abuse. To mange behaviours and feelings to enable a positive way forward in life. *Art Journaling group for adult survivors - enabling them to express their thoughts and feelings through creative activity such as collage; paint; poetry etc. *Public awareness activity within communities of Southend on Sea including range of fund-raising activities and public survey opportunities ie: market pitch, community events and campaign involvement. *Training and presentations to voluntary and statutory partners to consistently raise awareness of scope of specialist support services available. *Representation on key stakeholder groups across the community including: Safeguarding Adults Board; Missing Children & Child Exploitation Board; One in Four Group; Inter-professionals Group; Southend Information Advisory Group etc. *Engagement in Partnership working with Synergy Essex (Essex Rape Crisis Partnership) - working closely with CARA (Centre for Action on Rape and Abuse) and SERICC (South Essex Rape and Incest Crisis Centre). *Co-production and consultation activity with survivors, public and staff/volunteers to consistently identify gaps in service and enable clear development and planning going forward to meet growing demand and identify needs. *Dedication to Continued Professional and Personal Development for staff and volunteers including working with local training providers to enable student placement opportunities. *Lisa's Line - clothing rail for survivors unable to resource attire for interviews or new employment positions. Using high quality clothing donations to assist in times of need on a loan or keep basis. *Support to Local Authority commissioned production 'Prince Charming' - providing voice in awareness raising to schools on specialist support available for survivors of sexual violence. *Weekly drop in provision for Family Mosaic to support survivors requiring specialist support and advice on housing issues. *First Contact Navigator Triage service for all new referrals - one point of contact at initial stage of referral whether self referral or organisation/agency referral *First Meeting programme to support and welcome new survivors into the specialist support service - enabling clear pathway of support to be identified from the first session. *Ensuring safe, welcoming space for all service users including all ages; all genders; supporters/relatives as well as survivors.
recipientOrganization.name: SOS Rape Crisis

recipientOrganization.description: Home-Start Essex (HSE) is a leading family support charity based in Essex working to achieve healthy and positive outcomes for children and families. Our work comprises a long-established volunteer home visiting service, offering emotional and practical help to families experiencing difficulties, alongside a range of family groups, well-being programmes, courses and events. What makes our charity special, is that all our trained volunteers have lived experience as parents/carers themselves. We believe in the power of community mobilisation, and so invest in local areas to support local families. Our Vision is: ‘For every child and young person in Essex to grow up in a family that is strong, resilient and able to access the support they need; when and where they need it’ HSE recognises that bringing up children can be hard work. All parents and carers will, from time to time, encounter problems which make the task harder. The key to success is for parents and carers to be strong and resilient, so they can meet challenges head on, and navigate their way through or around them successfully. Through mobilising hundreds of volunteers, we support families to help themselves, developing parenting skills and improving connections in their community. Our volunteers support families struggling with: • Mental Health issues (including peri/post-natal depression, etc.) • Financial hardship • Physical health issues • Single parenthood • Low self-esteem and confidence • Domestic abuse • Isolation • Routines and boundaries • Bereavement and other significant life events The main activities of HSE are as follows: • Home-Visiting service, led by volunteers • Family Groups • School Readiness programme (e.g. Big Hopes-Big Futures) • Peri/post-natal support groups • Targeted mental health and wellbeing programmes • Counselling • Volunteer training and recruitment • Information, Advice, Guidance (IAG) and signposting • Food Bank Voucher distribution • Family activity days Our main funders are The Big Lottery Fund, BBC Children in Need, Virgin/Banardo’s PB-19yrs Contract, Essex Community Foundation, Clinical Commissioning Groups and local trusts. A new 5-Year Strategic Plan will be launched in March 2018 which will see HSE developing its funding streams to be more diverse; allowing the organisation to grow and build on excellent practice. Since April 2017, HSE has supported 368 families and 755 children, with over 200 trained volunteers offering 1,834 home visits, totalling 3,006 hours’ time across Essex. 95% of all frontline delivery continues to be entirely volunteer led. It is currently estimated that over the course of one year, the value of HSE volunteer time will be over £72,000 (ONS figures https://goo.gl/Uwz2cz). HSE measures impact across 14 individual areas of need (e.g. isolation, mental health, family conflict, etc.) with over 80% of families showing significant positive change. “My volunteer made a huge difference. Someone who’s not going to judge and always took the time to stop and listen”. We know that our model allows us to engage with those who would otherwise be considered ‘hard to reach’. Families frequently tell us the impact of a volunteer, giving their time freely, can be far more meaningful than a paid statutory professional. Isolation and mental health issues remain the top two concerns for most of the families we support, and this often means their ability to access mainstream services is limited. This provides HSE a unique opportunity to implement our proposed PICoD Project (Preventative IAG Co-Design) project; a three-year co-produced, family-led process that will develop a new model of information, advice and guidance (IAG). This will be aimed at those predominantly in the peri/post-natal period; a key period for those at risk of poor mental health and well-being. As an existing provider of peri/postnatal services in Harlow, and with a strong history of peer/ volunteer led practice, HSE are ideally positioned to lead on the project; building on our expertise and ability to engage families; ensuring that their voice is not only heard, but responded to in practical, real terms. HSE are confident that the project is deliverable as commitment has been tested with partners (e.g. Virgin/Banardo’s and University of Essex (UofE)) who say objectives are both realistic and achievable. By drawing on our existing network of partners, and engagement with families, HSE are keen to shape the future of family led practice. We believe this is achievable by harnessing the voices and opinions of service users as a tool; to shape and influence the way in which future information, advice and service delivery is commissioned. At HSE, our approach to project design, development and delivery is thorough and systematic. At concept stage, HSE appoints a Project Lead and a Project Delivery Team to draft delivery plans (in a standard format) and undertake initial research. This involves liaising with stakeholders (staff, service users, potential funders and partners, etc.); testing project feasibility; identifying resource needs; establishing project milestones/dependencies/budgets; and undertaking SWOT analysis. This forms the foundation for funding applications/development, as part of the new 2018 Funding Strategy. Upon funding success, our Development Team hands over to the Project Delivery Team, who refine proposals and manage the initiative on an ongoing basis, reporting back to Management, Trustees and Funders in a structured way. This gives assurance to stakeholders involved, that the way HSE delivers projects, is transparent and well managed.
recipientOrganization.name: Home-Start Essex

Upon funding success, our Development Team hands over to the Project Delivery Team, who refine proposals and manage the initiative on an ongoing basis, reporting back to Management, Trustees and Funders in a structured way. This gives assurance to stakeholders involved, that the way HSE delivers projects, is transparent and well managed.
recipientOrganization.name: Home-Start Essex

recipientOrganization.name: Lads Need Dads CIC
recipientOrganization.description: Who we are: Lads Need Dads CIC is a Not-For-Profit Community Interest Company, based in Tendring, North East Essex, set up to prevent potential problems and address existing ones where boys are missing a father figure in their lives. Our Mission: To empower and enable boys aged 11-15 with absent fathers or limited access to a male role model, to be motivated, responsible, capable, resilient and emotionally competent to prevent them from coming at risk of under achieving, offending, exclusion or dropping out of school. What we do: • Help boys through male-led group mentoring, to cope with problems and issues faced at home and school, and explore the important choices they face in their adolescent development, to prevent escalation of negative behaviour. • Provide boys with opportunities for adventure, to be tested and challenged, both physically and mentally. • Provide boys with practical life-skill training, community volunteering and peer mentoring opportunities. • Raise awareness and understanding of the important role fathers play in the emotional, mental and educational development and well-being of boys. Why we do it: In 2013 the Centre for Social Justice published Fractured Families: Why stability matters, which highlighted an alarming trend of fatherlessness across the UK. It found that a teenager sitting their GCSEs is more likely to own a smartphone than live with their father, (only 57 per cent of 15-year olds are still living with their fathers while 62 per cent own a smartphone), (1). Nationally almost one quarter of families with dependent children are lone-parent families. (2) This figure rises significantly in our poorest neighbourhoods, and can be as high as 75 percent. (3) Blanden (2006) (4), found a father’s low interest in his son’s education, for instance, reduces his boy’s chances of escaping poverty by 25% and at the more extreme end, 76% of all male prisoners in England and Wales had an absent father. Statistically males are the more vulnerable gender when it comes to alcohol and drug misuse, victims of murder, victims of suicide, homelessness. Lads Need Dads was set up to provide a preventative and early-intervention response to an ever-increasing social issue. Our services: ‘EQUIP’, is a six-month self-development group-work programme held in school including bush-craft and outdoor activities supported by a facilitator and a team of male mentors. Equips’ aim is to help boys cope with problems and issues faced at home and school, and explore the important choices they face in their adolescent development, to prevent escalation of negative behaviour. Engage, a practical life-skill and community volunteering programme follows Equip and takes place in the community for six-months and involves boys attending practical life-skill workshops and together with thier mentors, doing voluntary work for lone parents, pensioners and people with a disability within their local community. Jobs include, DIY, painting and decorating, gardening, shed building, etc. Inspire, a peer mentoring programme incorporating inspirational speakers and visits to inspiring places, completes the 18-month programme. We have run the 18-month pilot once through between March 2016 and August 2017 with excellent outcomes. We started another Equip Programme in May this year. This ended this month (Nov) and the boys off this programme are now attending Engage, the second part of the programme. Alongside the programme we provide on-going support for mums and carers via workshops, coffee mornings and a face-book support group. We raise awareness within the community by giving talks and presentations to community groups, attending public events etc. We run an open-ended check-in group for graduates of the programme one evening a month to keep the arm of support in place, should they need it. We run a fishing club in the summer which is open to any boy on the programme, graduate or new boy who fits our criteria. We are just about to start a guitar club for boys who want to learn to play the guitar but who can't afford lessons. All our services are provided free of charge. We have a growing team of 14 male volunteer male mentors, between the ages of 29 and 70, from a wide range of backgrounds and from the local community. Our Director board is made up of four professionals from education, social care, statutory services and the voluntary sector. We are just entering into our next round of recruitment so anticipate our volunteer numbers increasing. References: (1) Ibid, Ofcom, Children and Parents: Media User and Attitudes Report, 2013 (2) Office of National Statistics, General Lifestyle Survey Overview: A Report on the General Lifestyle Survey 2011, Chapter 3 – Households, families and people, 7 March 2013 [accessed via: http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/dcp171776_302210.pdf (2/7/14)] (3) Centre for Social Justice, Fractured Families: Why stability matters, London: Centre for Social Justice, 2013, p32. (4) Blanden, J. (2006). ‘Bucking the trend’: What enables those who are disadvantaged in childhood to succeed later in life? Working Paper No 31 Corporate Document Services. London: Department for Work and Pensions. (5) Prison Reform Trust 2015.

recipientOrganization.description: Hockley Public Hall has been serving the community of Hockley for over 100 years providing a low cost venue for small community and voluntary groups operating in the area who cannot afford the hire costs of larger local venues. When the Hall became a registered charity in 1948 its charitable objectives were recorded as being 'use by the public for the benefit of the people of Hockley and the surrounding area to increase recreation and education facilities'. Currently the Hall hosts a number of small community groups . These include a dance school, a slimming club, a majorette group, a yoga school, and a fitness group. The Hall also provides a venue for a group called Ark ll who provide special Sunday sessions for people who would normally be alone at the weekends. These groups are the Hall's regular users but the Hall also provides a popular venue for events such as quiz nights and celebrations such as the Queen's Jubilee. The Hall is also used to host children birthdays and family parties. The Trustees for Hockley Public Hall include representatives of the Parish Council and the church. The trustees are aware of the long record of service of the Public Hall which stretches back to its construction 124 years ago. The Hall has survived bomb damage in World War 2 and is the oldest community venue in Hockley. Over the past few years the Trustees have worked hard to raise funding to help refurbish the Hall's structure and facilities including the replacement of the roof and improving toilet facilities and disabled access. The trustees are aware of the important role the Hall continues to play in providing an affordable venue for small community groups in this difficult economic period, helping to support community cohesion and involvement in Hockley.
recipientOrganization.name: Hockley Public Hall

recipientOrganization.description: Lanarkshire Deaf Club provides support and advice for deaf people of all ages. We are volunteer led. This includes running and organising the social club for the deaf community and their families, a mother and toddler group during school holidays, a youth group and the formation of a 'drop in' service. We provide an opportunity for deaf families to have a safe environment where both hearing and deaf people are equal. During the mother's group we teach baby sign. In the future we will be restarting BSL sign language courses. The 'drop in' service is a service that the deaf community can access for assistance with correspondance, appointments or to be sign posted to the appropriate service ensuring that there is an appropriately qualified interpreter there. The service is aimed at all age groups and ethnicity. We support both deaf people with hearing children and hearing people with deaf children.

recipientOrganization.description: We are an active and vibrant parent led independent charity, set up in 1996, following extensive research, committed to helping improve the lives of families of children/young people (0-25) with any Special Educational Need or Disability (SEND) across Essex, including those with physical and/or sensory impairments, learning difficulties, mental health issues and emotional/behavioural problems of an enduring nature. Current highly successful and valued activities include Family Support Advisers working across Essex providing information, advice, emotional and practical support, addressing a wide range of issues, achieving positive outcomes improving health, social, emotional and economic well-being, strengthening and building resilience, enhancing stability and improving quality of life for the whole family. Our Siblings Support Group (brothers and sisters aged 8+, who are young carers) providing opportunities for them to have some time away from the family group to enjoy their childhood/meet others with similar experiences. recipientOrganization.description: Windmill Hill City Farm is a green oasis in an urban environment with a mission to bring experiences of food, farming and the environment to the heart of the city. It provides both facilities (working farm, gardens, café, community rooms) and services (education, social care, childcare) to its community. A significant part of our mission is about educating people about sustainable living and human impact on the natural world. The site is open 7 days-a-week and is free to access, providing an engaging, educational and enjoyable space to contribute to people’s wellbeing. Children and their families are a key audience for the city farm. We run an active schools programme that ensures that our educational messages are taken to as many children in different circumstances as possible. Over the past three years the farm has invested heavily in facilities and services for schools and families. Charitable fundraising has enabled provision of greenhouses, sheltered outdoor teaching spaces, a pond-dipping platform, learning centre and an outdoor kitchen. We have built a programme of activity that has led to strong relationships with inner city schools with limited capacity for outdoor learning.
recipientOrganization.name: Windmill Hill City Farm

recipientOrganization.description: The aims and objectives of the organisation are to primarily support young people between the ages of 10 - 24 with informal and formal education opportunities so they gain confidence and develop skills in order to feel empowered to make positive change in both their lives and within the community. Universal services are provided such as open access youth work sessions, as well as more targeted group work on specific issues such as sexual health and relationships, substance misuse, nutrition, self esteem and confidence, identity, protective behaviours and staying safe. The organisation is committed to a co-design model with service users having a voice in the focus of the targeted support. Young people engaged with the service are passionate about what they want to change and what issues they face on a daily basis within their community. We are working towards the establishment of a youth forum who will help the organisation shape its service delivery focus into the areas that cause the next generation of such a deprived community the most concern. We are interested in providing a safe space where, such an often unheard sector of the community, has a voice, where they are heard and are empowered to become part of the solution to the issues they face. Aptitude operates out of a community centre in Radford and draws in young people from Central North-East wards of Coventry, many of which are deprived as being in the top 10% of the most nationally deprived lower layer super output areas. One of the issues locally is the high number of unemployment and lack of aspiration amongst young people. As a result Aptitude has a particular emphasis on employment readiness and creating work experience opportunities through volunteering.
recipientOrganization.name: Aptitude Organisation CIC

recipientOrganization.description: Bath City Farm’s aim is to support a caring, healthy and cohesive community through the involvement of local people, especially those who are disadvantaged, in the development and maintenance of a productive green space. Our five core strategic objectives are: building a cohesive community; achieving improvements in people’s lives; stewarding the Farm’s resources; increasing skills and knowledge; connecting people to the natural world. We do this by delivering 15 different projects that fall within one of two pivotal Farm themes: 1) 'Roots to Health' - which aims to increase the health and wellbeing of adults with complex health needs; 2) 'Branching Out' - which aims to increase the health and wellbeing of children and young people, particularly those that are disadvantaged. Through these projects we encourage people to maximise their capabilities and gain the resilience and confidence to have control over their lives. We do this by providing fulfulling volunteering opportunties, supporting education, training and hands-on learning in gardening, animal care, cookery and land management and running therapeutic projects in a range of creative activities. In addition, we are open daily to the public, hold up to 10 public events a year and have a small café. We are very busy as our 2016 numbers show: 648 project participants; 4,530 people attended our programme of events; 1019 school/groups visitors; 18,000 general visitors.
recipientOrganization.name: Bath City Farm

recipientOrganization.description:
Our vision is that people coming to Bristol to seek sanctuary are welcomed and treated with dignity and respect.  

Our mission is to welcome asylum seekers and refugees in Bristol.  Together we create a place of solidarity and trust.  We challenge the injustices that we experience and witness in the UK.  Learning from each other we develop partnerships and links with the wider community to promote equality of opportunity for asylum seekers and refugees.  

Our activities:
We are open 3 days a week with services including: a drop in hub for wellbeing, drinks and snacks, games and activities, hot food; ESOL classes; a pre-school creche/Early Years Project and volunteering for service users.  Activities relevant to this application include:
1.	The Advocacy and Information Desk (AID): support, signposting and referrals to access services, ensure protection of human rights, find ways out of destitution, and get support to make fresh claims and eventually leave to remain.  
2.	The Asylum Support Project (ASP): advice on making applications for asylum support and accommodation and challenging refusals.  
3.	Destitution Support: asylum seekers and refugees who are not receiving financial support can access a food bank, toiletries, clothes and household items.
recipientOrganization.name: Bristol Refugee Rights

dataset.title: Quartet Community Foundation grants awarded April 2016 to March 2017

distribution.title: Quartet Community Foundation grants awarded April 2016 to March 2017

grants.description: We run a Welcome Centre for asylum seekers and new refugees in the centre of Bristol 3 days each week over 48 weeks of the year.  The Centre has developed over the course of 10 years with regular input from members (asylum seekers and refugees) who are encouraged to be involved in the running of the organisation from the time they join.  The organisation offers free English classes, computer classes, trips, advocacy and information, support with asylum applications, opportunities to take part in public speaking, to train to be an interpreter; families can use the Early Years project for children under 5, and more.  At the heart of the Centre there is a space for members to meet each other, develop friendships, and obtain emotional and wellbeing support.  They can access: a cooked meal, refreshments, games, arts and crafts, destitution bags, a free haircut, massages, community interpreters, be referred to the Bristol Bike Project, see the asylum nurse, meet with a mental health volunteer from MIND and more.  Additionally the organisation works in partnership with other groups in the city to host an event on Human Rights Day each year and activities and celebrations within National Refugee Week.  Last year at least 850 asylum seekers and new refugees benefited from our Welcome Centre.
grants.Impact Category: Promote reduction of isolation and disadvantage and access to local services
grants.title: Asylum Seeker and Refugee Well Being Project

recipientOrganization.description:
BF provides a high quality, professional psychotherapy and counselling service for individuals, children and families. The key aims are to:
 - Provide counselling and psychotherapy services to those who would not easily have access to them.
- Encourage understanding of the emotional barriers to healthy living, through consultation with professionals and organisations working with emotional vulnerability
- Demonstrate the effectiveness of the service through monitoring and evaluation, to inform and educate policy and service development
- Contribute to public understanding through training and public conferences on emotional aspects of individual, organisational and social health.
There are two main strand to the work: a fee- paying service and a free to service user, mental health service called Bridge in Schools (BIS), funded by contracts with schools and voluntary donations. BIS is our core charitable work. This year Bristol schools face real term budget cuts of between 10-15% of total budget, in addition to other pressures - growing pupil numbers and increasing mental health challenges in schools are resulting in a growing need for our work.
recipientOrganization.name: Bridge Foundation

recipientOrganization.name: Runnymede and Spelthorne CAB
recipientOrganization.description: Runnymede and Spelthorne Citizens Advice Bureau (CAB) is a fully independent registered charity (registered in 2009). It is a member of the national Citizens Advice Association. The aims of Citizens Advice are to provide advice people need for problems they face and to improve policies and practices affecting people's lives. There are two main offices, in Addlestone and Sunbury Library, offering drop-ins five and three days per week. Unpaid volunteers give their time to help their fellow citizens by providing free, independent, confidential and impartial advice on rights and responsibilities. The CAB also operates an outreach service at the Abraham Cowley Unit, for users of mental health services. There are also outreach services in Stanwell and Englefield Green. Runnymede and Spelthorne CAB provide a Home Visiting service to people who are housebound, as well as the Runnymede Rentstart (RR) service. RR is based in Addlestone and provides assistance with finding privately rented accommodation, providing a deposit in the form of a guarantee bond, rent in advance and tenancy support.  Support is given to singles and couples with no children who have low or no income. Rentstart aims to help vulnerable local people who are homeless or faced with homelessness. Runnymede and Spelthorne CAB is overseen by a committee of 9 Trustees, the Rentstart project has two part-time employees. Local solicitors and other contacts provide additional support.

recipientOrganization.description: WASLER is a specialist domestic abuse charity providing refuge accommodation, support and information to women, children and young people who have experience of domestic abuse.   We support and empower women, children and young people affected by domestic abuse to lead safe and independent lives offering practical support, safety planning, advocacy and safe accommodation.    'Building Equality' is a new project within WASLER - exploring the relationship between the  journey back towards paid work, gender and domestic abuse. The project is the first of it's kind within the United Kingdom and extends Women's Aid's services to include employability support.

grants.description: Building Equality (BE) is a new project within WASLER, exploring the relationship between employment, gender and domestic abuse. Its aim for service users is: women have increased financial independence via access to economic resources, education, paid labour market and routes out of poverty.     BE 'Digi, Aye!' project will be based around a women's only job club. Weekly drop-in (9am-5pm) session where women can meet in a safe, non-judgemental learning environment and be supported to explore options and address barriers to work. This will be a one-stop shop for budgeting support, universal credit applications, universal job match demands, CV updates, job search and applications etc.     When not being utilised as a job club - the space will be available for all service users to utilise internet/applications etc. with the support of their worker. recipientOrganization.description: We aim to enhance lives by providing bespoke support for 11-25 year olds to overcome day to day difficulties. This is achieved by boosting confidence by helping young people identify their strengths and develop strategies, through opportunities for them to feel more confident and empowered. Our Drop-in’s provide 1-1 sessions with a Support Worker allowing a young person to explore their difficulties and feelings, in a safe environment. Through these sessions we help them to improve their communication with peers, families and agencies so they are more resilient. By learning skills that will help them to problem solve their issues in the future more positively. By identifying their qualities, we progress onto a range of youth led group activities, this helps them to hone in on their often, hidden talents. Current projects include: Harwich Inspired Youth Action (HIYA)for 11-18 years-Young People making a difference to their community. Wildlife Project-for 11-25 years- Young People involved in activities that support local wildlife Volunteer Programme-for 18-25 years-an opportunity to develop their knowledge and practical skills. Each of the above provides a base for Young People to develop their ideas and gives them the opportunity to try new things.

grants.description: The charity plans to campaign to keep young people’s mental health on the agenda and keep young people’s experiences and voices at the centre of discussions, through making its Vs young activist group a core part of the charity’s work. Our grant would support this by part-funding the salary of the Youth Engagement Manager, a core post under the new strategy.

recipientOrganization.description: Oxford Hub is the centre for student social action in Oxford. Our aim is to support every student in Oxford to engage in social issues whilst university, empowering them to be active citizens for life. We achieve this by providing students with practical opportunities to tackle social and environmental issues and engage their peers in causes they care about. Last academic year we supported over 600 student volunteers on various student-led projects: for example, nearly 300 students tutored in local schools (with an average of 34% of pupils on FSM and 36% ESL pupils) to help local children and young people reach their academic potential; other volunteers ran free IT classes for older people to help promote connectivity and tackle loneliness; and some students ran free English Language lessons for recent migrants. In addition, we support students to incubate new volunteering project and social enterprise, such as board games to help encourage engagement in STEM subjects or a language exchange between students studying arabic and refugees. Lastly, to engage students in our activities and the issues they tackle, we held 112 events last academic year, ranging from volunteer fairs to workshops on tackling loneliness.
recipientOrganization.name: Oxford Hub

dataset.title: Grants awarded FY 2017-18

distribution.title: Grants awarded FY 2017-18

grants.description: The grant will solely go towards the 5 pilot projects: 3 in local schools, one in a care home and one IT class (at a neighbourhood community centre). All 5 pilot projects will be designed and led by students with disabilities. We will coordinate focus groups and surveys in May and June 2017. The focus groups will look at how we can improve marketing; relevant training; travel to and from pilot locations; and the volunteering experience itself so that it can be as accessible as possible to students with disabilities. The focus groups will pay particular attention to the concerns of those students who do not currently volunteer. Using recommendations from disabled students, we will implement new marketing and training processes for the beginning of the 2017-18 academic year, with the 5 projects launching in late October and running until early December. We will recruit 10 students with disabilities for each project; in total, the pilots will reach over 75 beneficiaries. In January 2018 we will run evaluation sessions, allowing each group of volunteers to reflect on their experiences and suggest further improvements, before rolling out recommendations and new processes to all our programmes and projects from April 2018.
grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety
grants.title: Equality & Inclusion Programme

recipientOrganization.description: The Ark T Centre harnesses the powers of creativity and human connection to change lives. We specialise in using the arts as a tool for personal empowerment and construct projects which address complex social issues such as rising mental health issues, social isolation, sexual violence and social injustice. Our current projects aim to increase emotional intelligence, develop leadership skills and rebuild people's aspirations for their future. We currently run ROAR, a festival which empowers disabled young people in the arts, HERSPACE a project which supports young women affected by sexual violence and/or have been victims of bullying.
recipientOrganization.name: Ark T Centre

dataset.title: Grants awarded FY 2017-18

distribution.title: Grants awarded FY 2017-18

grants.description: Our proposed social action project is to support the Young Oxford Creatives to form and establish themselves with the specific aim of designing, leading and evaluating ROAR, the first youth arts disability festival held in Oxford. We want this festival to be led by young people for young people and whilst the festival celebrates the work of disabled young people, the event itself is inclusive. We see this as an incredible opportunity to build a genuinely inclusive council of young people to inspire individual social change, through their own leadership journeys and social change through challenging stereotypes. Whilst the YOC will have a more comprehensive role within Oxford, ROAR is an event which will mobilise the group to carry out direct social action, examine the barriers in place that face young people with disabilities. Ark T also recognise that there are many economic barriers in place for families of disabled children and young people, and the YOC will focus on potential strategic options for dismantling these barriers. Ark T want to provide space, resources, belief, and guidance to this group in order to generate a new wave of diverse creative leaders who influence the future of culture in Oxford.
grants.Impact Category: Connect people with the arts, culture and heritage
grants.title: Young Oxford Creatives

recipientOrganization.description: BF provides a high quality, professional psychotherapy and counselling service for individuals, children and families. The key aims are to: - Provide counselling and psychotherapy services to those who would not easily have access to them. - Encourage understanding of the emotional barriers to healthy living, through consultation with professionals and organisations working with emotional vulnerability - Demonstrate the effectiveness of the service through monitoring and evaluation, to inform and educate policy and service development - Contribute to public understanding through training and public conferences on emotional aspects of individual, organisational and social health. There are two main strand to the work: a fee- paying service and a free to service user, mental health service called Bridge in Schools (BIS), funded by contracts with schools and voluntary donations. BIS is our core charitable work. This year Bristol schools face real term budget cuts of between 10-15% of total budget, in addition to other pressures - growing pupil numbers and increasing mental health challenges in schools are resulting in a growing need for our work.
recipientOrganization.name: Bridge Foundation

grants.description: Visyon will offer opportunities for their young service users to engage in volunteering activities within Visyon itself. Visyon have an onsite café which the young people will work within, serving visitors and staff. The young people will be provided with training in food hygiene, customer service and meet-and-greet skills as appropriate. They would be supervised by Visyon’s experienced team with specialist knowledge in mental health support, and led on a day-to-day basis by the café supervisor. at the end of the project, the young people will produce an exhibition of their work to showcase their skills, which will raise awareness of the work of Visyon to a wider audience and demonstrate the positive activities young people recovering from mental health issues are involved in. This will be part of an Awards evening, where their work will be celebrated alongside other achievements to the local community, parents and carers.

grants.title: Bromley Healthy Families
grants.description: Healthbox CIC specialise in community health & wellbeing projects. For this project, Healthbox will team up with Plus Dane Housing to offer a vibrant project aimed at improving the health & wellbeing of vulnerable and disadvantaged families on the Bromley Farm Estate, Congleton. This strong partnership between a CIC and a housing provider will help to pool a range of specialist resources ranging from extensive community project experience to community development approaches. The Bromley Healthy Families project will support parents and their primary school aged children by providing a range of stimulating workshops around healthy eating and healthy lifestyles which in turn will aim to reduce food bank dependency during school holidays (which is prevalent in Congleton), tackle poverty stricken households and enhance wellbeing amongst children and parents. This focused yet holistic approach to family support will make a positive and lasting difference. The funding will enable weekly workshops to take place during the school holidays for a year - including ingredients, professional tutors, recipes, educational materials, training workshops for parents and the purchase of cooking equipment to enable the project to become self-sufficient and parent-led after the 12 month period, leaving a lasting legacy and commitment towards healthy lifestyles.

grants.description: The grant will be used towards building a storage extension to our village hall to house equipment that is needed to maintain and improve usage by many of our regular clubs and societies of the community facility. Many provide health & wellbeing opportunities, especially for youth and the elderly within our community and beyond. Lack of storage space has prevented users from expanding and without the extra space they may be lost to our community. This is generally for bulky items, which although used regularly currently have to be housed half a mile away and transported to the village hall when needed. This is not only tiresome for our user leaders - all are volunteers - .but also off putting. Several users would like to expand to provide more opportunity to an identified need, but are unable to do so. For example, our youth table tennis club would like to expand but there is no more storage space for another table tennis table, and they are too bulky to easily transport. Planning permission has been granted for the extension (West Oxfordshire District Council PP-05672057).
grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety
grants.title: Finstock Village Hall storage extension

recipientOrganization.description: The Trust protects and provides access to the military heritage of the county through its museum, opened in 2014.It conserves and interprets their collection, providing access to rich archives for researchers and producing varied exhibitions and learning opportunities. SOFO’s principal objective for the next ten years is to increase access through far greater audience-focused interpretation activity. The SOFO collection is unique to the county. Although the regiments themselves have been absorbed into larger regimental groups, family connections with many of the soldiers who served in the Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire Light Infantry and the Oxfordshire Yeomanry persist. The number of people in the county with memories of and personal connections to conflict, both past and current, is huge. The heritage is important as a resource with which to increase people’s understanding of the nature of military conflict, and its effect on individuals both on the front and at home, with specific relevance to the local area. The museum displays include comparisons and references to modern day culture and events. Their development was influenced by engagement with youth groups, schools and other partners. Regular activities a lecture programme drawing on some of the best academic, professional and amateur speakers in the region, and community events, such as a recent candlelit service for the Woodstock community commemorating the Christmas Truce of 1914 and lead by actor, Robert Hardy. An excellent formal education programme saw over 1000 children take part in First World War workshops for KS2 and 3 during the autumn of 2016. Partnership working with The Oxfordshire Museum has seen the development of regular informal activities for families with children. SOFO has an increasing number of volunteers who have been working to support outreach and exhibition activities.
recipientOrganization.name: Soldiers of Oxfordshire Trust (SOFO)

dataset.title: Grants awarded FY 2017-18

distribution.title: Grants awarded FY 2017-18

grants.description: We will work with members of the Asian community to design three cultural days, which will be specifically aimed to engage with British Asian families as museum visitors/users. Two events will be hosted at the museum, and a third larger cultural event will take place at a site within Oxford. These three day-long events will feature children's learning activities based on highlighting shared histories already uncovered in the recent research projects, as well as an Indian musical performance themed around the Great War, and a public talk about the war and its connection with Indian soldiers. These three events will help integrate local communities by bringing them together in a shared heritage programme. They will also have a valuable educational impact; deepening historical awareness beyond what is currently taught in school curriculums, and particularly supporting the learning of a diverse cross-section of young people.
grants.Impact Category: Maximise ability to strengthen community cohesion and build social capacity
grants.title: The Living Legacy of Indian Soldiers

recipientOrganization.description: Promoting community integration and cohesion: Increasing access to participation, reduce barriers to access for a diverse community experiencing complex issues such as disability, poverty and social exclusion in community life. We work to empower and support local families to develop and co-deliver services meeting crucial community needs whist celebrating peoples' unique abilities, promoting and preserving equality Our main focus is around providing early intervention services supporting children with the social and emotional support needed to help them fulfil their potential and break the cycles of underachievement, which in turn will lessen the chance of them adopting antisocial or negative behaviour throughout life. Children including children with disabilities and families most in need have enhanced prospects in life through reducing barriers to engagement. Volunteering opportunities inspire local residents with low self esteem to recognise and achieve their potential, through providing access to guidance, advice, training and resources supporting confidence building, raising expectations and aspirations thus improving employability. Affordable socially wide-ranging opportunities breaking down barriers increases disadvantaged children’s prospects to improve their immediate wellbeing and their future life chances. Our project provides families, children and young people with a hub in which to build social capital and cohesion within their community.
